e8f5714f8300924b01fd482fbfc8ee338012a972: Starmer is undergoing his deepest political crisis yet
c18cff440c694fe05bef3aa121d3f41c7a3cb9be:
The apology was made at the start of a speech that was supposed to focus on investment in disadvantaged local communities, one of Labour's heart issues. However, it is clear that the Epstein scandal has now reached Starmer's absolute closeness, which means that other politics end up in the background.

Anyone who follows British politics is used to loud headlines, fierce debates in the House of Commons and frequent ministerial changes. Now, however, everything revolves around the question of what the Prime Minister actually knew when Mandelson was appointed to the prestigious ambassador post in Washington.  In the House of Commons yesterday, Starmer admitted he was aware of Mandelson's contacts with Epstein after the 2008 conviction. But during the pre-appointment security clearance, Mandelson claimed he barely knew Epstein - a lie that led to his sacking over a dawn phone call on the US east coast last September.  Demands for publication In the House of Commons, demands are now growing to publish the documents that show how Mandelson was investigated before his appointment. Starmer supports the demand, but the police - who have opened a preliminary investigation against Mandelson - have stopped publication for the time being. Frustrating for the Prime Minister, to use his own words from today's press conference.  Starmer assures that he had absolutely no information about the close relationship between Mandelson and Epstein that he has today. Perhaps the Prime Minister of Great Britain should ask himself how the security clearance for one of the heaviest assignments in the foreign administration is done?

Documents from the US Department of Justice, consisting of both emails and photos, testify to close contacts between Epstein and the British heavyweight.  That Mandelson appears in the picture in old white underpants in Epstein's apartment in Paris is in this context a minor detail; significantly more serious is that he shared market-sensitive information and gave Epstein insight behind the scenes into London's political top echelons, including during the coalition negotiations in 2010.

8919d390423ce4f2347ff4d9e924ab06d9308f62: Sweden Democrats party leader Jimmie Åkesson is in Jokkmokk to visit the annual market held in the town. In connection with the visit, Åkesson had planned to participate in the traditional reindeer race, but the SD leader needed to think again. According to information to TV4 Nyheterna, Åkesson skips the competition at the request of Säpo. Several politicians on site have been informed of an "incident" by the authority. The party leader tells TV4 Nyheterna that he learned that someone dropped a weapon-like object near him. - I heard that it was a revolver or a pistol, says Jimmie Åkesson. Säpo's press service does not want to go into whether they warned the SD leader about a firearm. - Our dialogue with our guardians is not something we can go into, so I cannot say anything about it. It is part of the protection itself, says Säpo's spokesperson Johan Wikström. Information about threats The Sweden Democrats' press department cannot confirm whether Åkesson has received threats. - The information I have is that he is not running, and it is after a recommendation from Säpo, says party spokesperson Emma Kareld. It is not the first time Jimmie Åkesson has had to leave Jokkmokk's market. In 2014, his book signing at the market was stopped due to threats, which SVT Norrbotten reported on at the time.

5ab0e6cc4b4336fb0f3e7e5813c5000698a0a1b2: When the nuclear agreement between the US and Russia now expires, for the first time in over 50 years there are no restrictions on the world's most destructive weapons. According to Jakob Hallgren, director of the Foreign Policy Institute, there is a great risk that a long period of disarmament will now stop – or reverse. - This is the first time since the early 1970s that there is no agreement regulating the number and use of the most powerful nuclear weapons between the two countries that have the most in the entire world, he says. Regulated the most dangerous weapons The agreement that is now expiring has been about limiting strategic nuclear weapons, above all intercontinental missiles that can be fired from the US at Russia - or vice versa. In recent decades, these agreements have led to a sharp reduction in the world's nuclear arsenals. - During these 50 years, they have gone from a maximum of 70,000 nuclear weapons down to 12,000 today. It is a result of successive reductions that are now stopping – or, in the worst case, reversing. According to Hallgren, the risks already exist today. One of the biggest problems is that the US and Russia can no longer agree on new agreements. Today, China is estimated to have around 600 nuclear weapons, but Hallgren points to information which claims that the country may be on its way to 1,000 or 1,500. - China is now the factor that makes it impossible to come to an agreement. The US has said it wants China on board, but the Chinese say no. Increased tensions - also in Europe When there is no agreement that regulates the most devastating nuclear weapons, tensions in the outside world also increase, says Hallgren. The expert emphasizes that even a limited use of nuclear weapons would have extreme consequences. - Even the smallest nuclear weapon would have completely devastating effects, with hundreds of thousands - if not millions - of people injured or killed. 51966fc644c80b4535cac1af0f3d7428b447b5b1: The EU's high-speed rail hits its first hurdle: Money
a8d3a92b950d1f617f1ac089b10e5366d7433710: This is because the European Commission can indeed present a plan and call on the member states to implement it. But the funding itself must still come from the countries' own, often already strained budgets. From Berlin to Dresden by high-speed train In the south of Berlin, a new railway line shines in the sun. Double tracks, high noise barriers and a nail-straight stretch to the south. It is Germany's newest high-speed line, which opened at the beginning of December 2025 and makes the journey between Berlin and Dresden ten minutes faster. The project took 20 years to plan and seven years to build – but without any delays. The next step is to extend the route to the Czech capital Prague. Then the travel time between Berlin and Prague will be reduced to two and a half hours, compared to almost five hours today. Such a project is exactly what the European Commission wants the member states to invest in. Underinvestment, cheap tickets and short-term thinking But according to Christian Böttger, it will take years before a similar project can be inaugurated in Germany – or in Europe as a whole. According to him, billions are missing to even renovate the existing railway. The funds that do exist are often used for short-term solutions or for politically popular measures, such as lowering the price of train tickets. In Germany, years of underinvestment are clearly visible. Only about 62 percent of the trains run on time. Sweden is average within the EU, but still manages better, with around 87 percent on time. - In such a situation, to believe that new high-speed lines will be built within 15 years is wishful thinking, he says.

5eab4f6c2ad4e94ef42e65cff4969f695f3a2a20: "It can go from bare ground to half a meter of snow in no time"
d39132ccb5849bd8b9e5720520d6590fbfc7245e: Thursday evening and Friday can be messy in parts of Skåne. Previously, an orange warning for snowfall combined with wind has been issued for south-eastern Skåne, and in the southern and central parts of the county a yellow warning has been issued for similar weather conditions. The warnings apply from five o'clock on Thursday afternoon and extend until two o'clock on Friday afternoon. - In the south-eastern parts, there may be upwards of 20 centimeters of snow, locally more. There will also be a fresh to strong easterly wind - and then you know there will be snowdrifts in Österlen, says TV4 Nyhetern's meteorologist Peter Kondrup. "Bare ground to half a meter of snow in no time" Drift formation is a recurring problem in the open landscapes of Scania. Despite a snowfall of around 20 centimetres, the snow depth can vary significantly, which can affect both major and minor roads. - If you've ever been to Skåne, you know that it can go from bare ground to half a meter of snow in no time. There is nothing to stop the snow, but it drifts from one place to another and unfortunately often accumulates on the road. The advice is not to go out in traffic if you really don't have to, says Peter Kondrup. The last time there was an orange warning in approximately the same area in south-eastern Scania, a large part of the forecast was missed. - There were not as large quantities as feared and therefore there were not as many problems as had been expected. However, it remains to be seen how it will turn out this time – forecasts are forecasts, says Peter Kondrup. Risk of ice slippage Along the Öresund coast in the west, mild air will move in from the south, which can lead to freezing rain and ice slippage. - So it can be really noisy in Skåne tomorrow, with drifting snow in Österlen and risk of icy conditions in the west. In addition to Skåne, SMHI has issued a yellow warning for snowfall in parts of Halland and Västra Götaland counties. The warning applies from six o'clock on Friday morning and extends from just north of Varberg up to Trollhättan. During Friday, the weather moves north and in the West

0f26a16963f33479ac7a6fd0165dcf89db86f2c2: Swedish society fails to stop violence in intimate relationships
bb1fe796044e846e372c041cee147d3ccd82b4ec: The National Board of Health and Welfare has gone through 98 cases where children and adults in the years 2019 to 2024 have been killed or subjected to serious violence. Among these there are 41 cases involving children and in half of those cases it is the child's own parent who exposed them to the violence. Is it a failure? - You have to say that. When we have gone through these 98 cases, they are cases that have fallen between society's safety nets and then suffered fatal violence, have been murdered or serious violence, says Björn Eriksson in Nyhetsmorgon. Difficult to put together the puzzle The survey adds to previous reports on intimate partner violence to identify where society is failing. - We know what the risk factors are. Often there has been contact with the health and medical services. The police have been aware of them and social services have been aware. But it has been difficult to piece together this complex picture as it has been. That is what has broken, says Björn Eriksson. The National Board of Health and Welfare points out that these are unusual, but very serious crimes. - The vast majority of parents do not harm their children and the vast majority of women are not killed by a partner. But every case is so serious. We have an obligation to better prevent, says Moa Mannheimer, licensed psychologist and investigator at the National Board of Health and Welfare. Must listen more to the children The authority has several proposals for measures that must be presented to the government. An important part is more collaboration. - We can see in retrospect that the police had certain duties, the social service had certain duties and the health care service others. But putting the puzzle together and assessing risks in a structured way - that has been missing in these cases, says Moa Mannheimer. Another measure identified is that the child's situation must be strengthened. - You need to listen more to the children's voice both within healthcare, the police and social services. We need to take steps forward and not always just listen to the parents' version, but also take in the whole, says Björn Eriksson.
d0603da993f7c8a88ba4b850c913a9f7fde57595: 40 guinea pigs in urgent need of new homes
ac38a9d07d9b6a5d78a4425981f9df7e21faf9be: A week and a half ago, Djurens vänner in Staffanstorp in Scania received an emergency call from a family who could no longer care for the 30 guinea pigs they had at the time. Actually, the animal shelter did not have room for more animals, but still chose to move in. - We still felt that the situation was so big. The family really needed help, says Linnéa Stålhandske, operational director of Friends of the Animals Skåne.  More guinea pigs than expected When the animal friends arrived at the family in Staffanstorp, they were greeted by more animals than expected – 40 guinea pigs and a turtle. Guinea pigs become fertile as early as three to four weeks of age, which means they can reproduce quickly if kept together.  - Then they often mate with those nearby. If it is then a mother or a sister, it will be inbreeding. To avoid further reproduction, all males have now been neutered. When the guinea pigs were taken into care, fur and claws were left behind. Among the guinea pigs was "Grandma Rosiepuff", the oldest guinea pig who is believed to be the mother of many of the others. - She is probably related to all of them. She is the oldest guinea pig we have received, says Linnéa Stålhandske in Nyhetsmorgon.  "Looking for the perfect homes" After the case drew attention in social media, the animal shelter has received many expressions of interest. At the same time, care is taken to only place the guinea pig with serious animal owners.  - We do not sell small animals to be kept in cages. We do not sell small animals to be toys for children, of course. So we look for the perfect homes.  Guinea pigs can live between five and ten years if cared for properly. They need large areas to move around, such as a paddock or their own room, and should never be kept alone. They require companionship, a proper diet of fresh vegetables and free access to hay.

0d544c0d825088a3c4b4496e655bdb0388524254: Sami artisans bet everything on Jokkmokk's market
bd62b90d14840f48460ecd003757d72a2ba091cb: In her workshop on the farm, Julia Rensberg works with duodji, the traditional Sami craft. She makes bonnets, jewelery and art objects from reindeer antler, leather and wood for Jokkmokk's market. Despite the fact that e-commerce has grown in importance, the market is still the most important sales opportunity of the year for many Sami artisans. Combining crafts and reindeer herding Julia and many other Sami craftsmen combine crafting with reindeer herding. During the winter, spring and summer, reindeer husbandry takes up most of the time, while autumn is devoted to handicrafts. The work is long-term and already in the spring of the year before, planning begins for next year's market. - Yes, for me it is like that, at the market you sell for the whole year. After all, the market is the target, because it is precisely Sami craftsmanship that you want to see, look at and feel. So you prefer to buy on the spot, it's not something you just order. But you want to see what you get, says Julia Rensberg. Long-term planning for the future The materials, reindeer antler, hide and wood, for the craft often have to dry for one to two years in order not to crack and break during the crafting itself, which requires careful planning. Julia Rensberg emphasizes the importance of being careful with both materials and resources to secure the opportunities of future generations. - The material should ideally dry for one to two years, so this spring I started thinking about the market that will come in 2027. It takes time and you have to be careful both with materials and resources and think far ahead and also make sure that there is material left for future generations, says Julia Rensberg.

Police in Arizona suspect she has been abducted from her home outside of Tucson and are investigating the incident as a crime. Nancy Guthrie was last seen late Saturday night, January 31, when she returned home to her residence. When she didn't show up at church the following morning, friends and family raised the alarm, and she was reported missing at lunchtime on Sunday. Demanding ransom US media have reported signs of a break-in and traces of blood in the home. However, authorities have been tight-lipped on details and have not publicly confirmed exactly what was found, citing the ongoing investigation. The incident has gained further attention after several media outlets, including TMZ, reported receiving messages demanding a ransom for Nancy Guthrie's release.  The police have not yet confirmed that the claims come from an actual perpetrator – but have not dismissed them either. "When messages come to us, we treat it like any evidence," Pima County Sheriff Chris Nanos told CBS News. The family's plea Four days after the disappearance, Savannah Guthrie, along with her siblings, posted a video on Instagram in which they directly address the person who may be holding their mother captive. - We are ready to talk. But we live in a world where voices and images can be easily manipulated. We have to be absolutely sure she's alive. And that you have her. We want to hear from you, and we are ready to listen, she says.  She also tells us that her mother lives with constant pain and depends on her medicine to survive.  - Everyone is looking for you, mother, everywhere. We will not rest. b3afa51bb8bfa0f9f1ba6ad1bd4faf1e33c0b5d2: Want to make it easier to deport rapists
4dc9ba05bf4a07ecf19b866f37095063bcb801fd: Today, international rules require courts to make an individual assessment before a person with refugee status can be deported, even in the case of serious sexual crimes. The government believes that this has led to people convicted of rape in some cases having to stay in Sweden. The government wants rape and other serious sexual crimes to always be considered extremely serious crimes when considering deportation. - Rapists must be able to be deported. It doesn't get any weirder than that, says Migration Minister Johan Forssell (M) to TV4 Nyheterna. Wants to get other countries on board According to Forssell, Sweden is the first to come out with the initiative, but the government hopes to get other countries on board, mainly within the EU and the Nordics. The work is now starting at the UN level and the process may be long, even if movement is hoped for already this year. - Sweden will soon have the toughest regulations in the Nordics for criminal deportations, but it is not enough. We also want to change the international framework, says Forssell. In parallel, the government is expected to present new Swedish legislation this spring, which could lead to more criminal deportations. The individual examination in court must remain, but the government wants rape to always weigh very heavily in the assessment. Dismisses symbolic politics The background is that Swedish courts, with reference to current practice and international conventions, in some cases judged that the crime was not serious enough for deportation. The government therefore wants to influence how the refugee convention is applied, including through changes in UNHCR's governing documents. Forssell dismisses the initiative as symbolic politics, but admits that the process can be both difficult and time-consuming. - This is work that has not been touched on for a very long time, he says.

202cba480cac7391d6121a49ed2d6557fd113f76: High prices made customers choose more unhealthy food
f262f132f0face24b63136ebcd990245b604f254:
Fish, fruit and vegetables, as well as vegetarian products, were phased out and instead slim soda and minced pork went into the shopping basket, when food prices rose the most during 2022-2023. This is shown in a research report from AgriFood Economics, which is a collaboration between the Swedish University of Agriculture and Lund University. If the dietary change persists, it can make us sicker. 

- The fact that we reduce the intake of fruit and vegetables and also dietary fibre, has had a negative effect on public health. Above all, cardiovascular diseases could increase if we continued to eat this way over time, says Jonas Nordström, who is associate professor of economics and one of the report's authors.  Does not buy fresh fish Eva Ahlgren from Malmö shops with her husband and grandchildren at Ica Mathuset in Åkarp, Scania. She notes that they never bought very much fruit and vegetables, because the husband is not that fond of vegetables, but they buy less fish today than before the price increases.

- Maybe frozen fish in that case. Fresh is very expensive, she says. 

Lars Håhus, who is a regular customer in the store, belongs to those who have not changed their purchasing habits at all in recent years.

- I'm as stingy as I've always been and buy what I want and what's the best price, he says with a smile.  Hitting low-income earners Jonas Nordström and his research colleagues at AgriFood Economics could also see that it was the cheapest goods that received the highest percentage price increases. A phenomenon known as "cheapflation".

- It is often households with fairly small margins who choose the cheap products. In this way, it can be said that cheapflation and the inflation we have had have affected low-income households to a greater extent, notes Jonas Nordström. Trying to influence customers But what responsibility does the trade have in connection with cheapflation? 

ICA trader Patrik Jonsson believes that he does what he can to get customers to choose the more useful goods. In his store, for example, margins have been lowered on fruit
4d73b6ccca06feb50fc6e58b72bef10f43bc7680: Bengt, 77, had his birthday ruined by storm Leonardo
ed4cf2d32f575245c56ac80a35553f63486f0c4b: Bengt Lundblad from Mölnlycke turns 77 today. He is on holiday in Sitio de Calahonda, a small village located between Malaga and Marbella, with his family. But the storm Leonardo has put a damper on the birthday plans. - We had intended to walk around in shorts and some light clothing. But it didn't amount to much, says Bengt Lundblad. - We have seen terrible weather. It started last night and it thundered. In Andalusia, the region where Sitio de Calahonda is located, 3,500 have been evacuated, red warnings are in effect and in some places the heavy rain has already started to cause flooding. Thousands of rescue workers have been deployed to the areas believed to be worst affected. Boardwalk destroyed In Sitio de Calahonda, the boardwalk has gone into the sea. This also applies to parts of the plot that belong to Bengt's hotel. - I thought: What on earth? It wasn't destroyed yesterday, but it happened this morning. I've never seen anything like it. - And it continues to blow. So it's great weather. Bengt Lundblad and the family also celebrated his 74th birthday at the same place. - Then we had sunshine and there were sunbeds and laps of sun. So there are tremendous contrasts. "People stay inside" When asked what the atmosphere is like in the village, the birthday boy replies that he doesn't know. - There aren't that many people out, so we don't meet that many. They stay inside, people down here. After all, they also warned us - we shouldn't go out, they said. But Bengt Lundblad does not feel particularly worried about himself. - We have a good hotel that stands firm, he says and continues: - You have to stay away from the sea. Now we are actually sitting in a restaurant by the sea. But it's on solid ground so it won't fall down. On Friday, the storm will subside and Bengt Lundblad and his family will remain in Calahonda next week as well. - So we hope for a few sunny days.

President Donald Trump's Middle East envoy Steve Witkoff and Iran's Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi lead the respective delegations in Oman, which have often acted as mediators between the countries.  The talks were confirmed by both sides late Wednesday after some uncertainty about the time and place. Focus on the nuclear program The US delegation wants to investigate "zero nuclear weapons capability" for Iran, according to White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt, who emphasizes that Trump has "many options at his disposal beyond diplomacy", reports AFP. The talks come shortly after widespread protests in Iran, where human rights groups report tens of thousands dead after heavy crackdowns.

- They are negotiating, Trump says of Iran.

- They don't want us to attack them, we have a large fleet heading there, he adds, referring to the group of aircraft carriers he called an "armada".

Vice President JD Vance says Trump "will talk to everybody, he will try to accomplish what he can through non-military means and if he feels the military is the only option, he will ultimately choose it." Regional concerns and diplomatic hopes German Chancellor Friedrich Merz calls on Iran's leadership to "really start talks" and warns of "great fear of military escalation in the region". Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan says that "the parties want to give room for diplomacy" and that conflict "was not the solution".

According to the New York Times, the US has agreed to exclude regional actors from the talks, but missile and militia issues can still be discussed.  The Institute for the Study of War states that "Iran continues to show inflexibility in meeting US demands, reducing the likelihood that Iran and the US will be able to reach a diplomatic solution".

Iran has warned to strike back against US bases if attacked. 

- We are ready to defend ourselves and it is the President of the United States who must choose between compromise or war, said General Mohammad Akraminia.

In December, a video was published in which Francis warns other Africans: - You will end up in the military even if you have never served, and you will be sent to the front. Many friends have died for money, Francis says in the video. Viral video shows abuse Soon after, a video of Francis spread on social media. In uniform and with a land mine strapped to his chest, he is threatened by a Russian-speaking person who says that Francis will be used as a "can opener" to advance Russia's positions.  According to CNN, more and more Africans are being lured to Russia with promises of high wages and citizenship. Twelve African soldiers from Ghana, Nigeria and Uganda, among others, tell CNN that they were promised civilian jobs, but once in Russia have been forced to sign military contracts in Russian without an interpreter.  Many have had their passports confiscated and have not received any salary. - I have been here for seven months and have not received a cent, says one soldier anonymously to CNN. A soldier CNN spoke to believes that the African soldiers are given the most dangerous assignments at the front. - When you have stepped into the Russian army, you will either flee or die, says recruit Patrick Kwoba to CNN.  African governments warn Several African governments, including in Uganda, South Africa and Kenya, have warned that their citizens are being tricked into the war.  Ukraine's ambassador to Kenya, Yurii Tokar, also calls on African countries to stop recruitment.  - If they are at the front, they are our enemies, and Ukraine will defend itself. "Because Jagland has immunity as the former head of an international organization, Ekokrim has asked the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to take the initiative to lift the immunity," the authority writes in a press release. Norway's Foreign Minister Espen Barth Eide agrees with the Ecocrime Authority that Jagland's immunity must be lifted. - It is important that this issue is clarified. Then Jagland's immunity cannot stand in the way of an investigation. I have therefore decided that Norway should present a proposal to the Council of Europe's Committee of Ministers that Jagland's immunity should be lifted, says the foreign minister. Taking the investigation in stride Thorbjørn Jagland's defense lawyer, Anders Brosveet, however, takes the accusations against his client in stride. He tells VG that they will cooperate with the investigation and submit the requested documentation. - And based on what we have found, we are calmly looking at the outcome. It is first and foremost good for Jagland to get an authoritative clarification from Ekokrim, rather than the entire press corps carrying out its own little private investigation, says Brosveet. 8379186ca647eca6e25ad19e34acc1074bbf8026: More and more people are asking AI for dating advice - the psychologist: You should think about that
720d18b9711156d13bfeba8e583fd3d856114b87: According to an American study, one in four singles in the United States, and almost half of Generation Z, use AI to, among other things, analyze messages when dating online. One of those who use AI as a springboard in their dating is Dilara Chakali. - When I went to therapy, I felt: One hour a week was not enough for me. I wanted to reflect more. I wanted to understand myself more, how I function in dating, says Dilara Chakali in Efter fem. "Not so strange" Dilara Chakali says that she uses AI to get straight answers, but emphasizes that it is she herself who decides which advice she takes to heart. - I want "the ugly truth", she says.  - Then of course I choose how I act on it. I want to believe that I have the self-awareness that I don't act on everything it says, she says. Psychologist Maria Farm believes that it is a natural human behavior to ask for advice. And in this way, it is understandable that more and more people are using AI in these matters. - I think it is a natural consequence. That it is there and that we also use it in psychological matters, I don't think that is so strange in itself, says Maria Farm in Efter fem. The psychologist's advice: See it as a supplement Farm sees no major problems with using AI as support, but urges you to ask yourself the question for what purpose you are asking a question, as it can become destructive in the long run if you constantly have to ask and cannot make decisions yourself. - I have many clients who are a bit anxious, full of anxiety and they sometimes need to practice not actually asking so many questions about it, it could be the relationship, but it could also be their own health.  - With me, they get to practice standing up for their own opinion or maybe not asking for completely certain answers all the time, adds Farm. Maria Farm recommends that AI be used as part of a larger palette when it comes to big decisions in life. - If you are thinking about something as big as divorce, also ask a person. It doesn't have to be a therapist, but some wise person you trust

770d810d50094965101f2da04fb81ea398bde68d: The meteorologist: That's why the Russian cold refuses to let go
a9cff08032cb77552a536a8a010fcb00023732c4: Since the middle of January, a high pressure has settled over Sweden. Especially high pressure and freezing temperatures go hand in hand during the winter months, not least when it becomes prolonged.  In meteorology, such a locked-in high pressure is called a high-pressure blockage, and is what lays the foundation for weather extremes. - Blocking high pressure creates winter's cold snaps and summer's heat waves, explains TV4 meteorologist Ulrika Elvgren. Therefore the cold remains The reason why the high pressure has become permanent is partly that it consists of slowly sinking air, that is to say that it receives its air supply from above. The cold air is also heavier than the warm, and air accumulation (high pressure) therefore thrives in the atmosphere closest to the ground. In order to break the high-pressure bucket, an extensive low pressure with a substantial portion of mild air is therefore required.  But during periods of high pressure blocking, the low pressure is instead guided around the high pressure and the cold, as now, is allowed to remain undisturbed.  - It's a locked-in weather situation and we've had this high pressure now for several weeks, but it might start to weaken a little during the next week and let in a little more weakened frontal zones, says Ulrika Elvgren. - We have already received a little more snow in southern Sweden. But it looks like the cold air won't let go. A cold domain lies over the whole of northern Europe and into the Russian continent and further east, she adds. "No clear mild air coming in" Although the high pressure may change at the beginning of next week, one should not count on the cold air to disappear because of it. Further ahead, the forecasts are too uncertain to be able to draw any conclusions. - It looks like colder air will return as we approach the middle of February. We have no clear mild air coming in. Maybe sometime in the second half, towards the end of February. But the first half of February still looks very cold, says Ulrika Elvgren. - There is no hope of any spring heat before Valentine's Day. From February 15 starts

Reduced dependence on the United States The play is done against the background of Canada's decision to expand its air combat forces with 88 new planes. 16 of these, F-35 Lightning from American Lockheed Martin are already booked and ordered. Concerns about the reliability of the United States as a partner have grown in Canada following Donald Trump's repeated comments about making Canada the 51st state of the United States. The opposition now also points out that Prime Minister Mark Carney himself in his famous speech in Davos recently emphasized that Canada must act more independently and reduce its dependence on the United States and invest more in cooperation with medium-sized countries. 

- If Mark Carney completes the purchase of the F-35, it proves that his statements in Davos were just a PR stunt, says Don Davies. Saab hopes for production line Yesterday's marking from two of Canada's opposition parties comes at the same time that Saab announced at the Singapore Air Show that the defense group is considering establishing a production line in Canada that can serve not only Canadian needs but also build Gripen planes for other countries. - If we were to win in Canada, we would not only build for Canada. We would see it as a hub for exports, said Mikael Franzén, head of marketing for Saab's Gripen program at the Singapore Airshow yesterday. A prosecutor from the National Anti-Corruption Unit is investigating the suspected misconduct together with the police's anti-corruption unit at Noa, the national operational department. Lotta Finstorp, governor of Norrbotten county, commented on the suspicions yesterday. - These are very serious allegations. I am now waiting to receive a signal from the police and prosecutors to be able to know exactly what this is about. My information is based on what you have reported in the media, she said. Today, the County Administrative Board in Norrbotten called the staff to an extraordinary meeting due to the disclosure. "Requested employees not to talk to the media" "That's right. Your reporting has raised questions among our employees and we informed you that we currently do not know more than what you have conveyed. We hold regular information meetings with all employees with the aim of keeping everyone updated on the operations. We also hold such if necessary between the regular information meetings, which we carried out today," writes the authority's head of communications Fredrik Hedlund in an email. Sources from within the County Administrative Board state that during the crisis meeting, management urged the agency employees not to speak out if they are contacted by the media, but instead to refer to the communications department. According to Fredrik Hedlund, the purpose was "not to urge employees not to talk to the media" but to inform the employees to contact the communications department "for support". - Maybe that's what they meant, but that's not how it was said, says an employee at the County Administrative Board to TV4 Nyheterna. 0de1492902384beaaeafed4ebffa7bbe448106dd: Sweden Democrats party leader Jimmie Åkesson is in Jokkmokk to visit the annual market held in the town. The police have not yet found any weapon. At first there were reports that politicians had been threatened, but the police deny this. Säpo denies Säpo's press service does not want to go into whether they warned the SD leader about a firearm. - Our dialogue with our guardians is not something we can go into, so I cannot say anything about it. The Sweden Democrats' press department cannot confirm whether Åkesson has received threats. - The information I have is that he is not running, and it is after a recommendation from Säpo, says party spokesperson Emma Kareld. 0307efeec21ac6d2458ba29b61cf5029c4281810: The savings expert's happy message: "It speaks for an interest rate cut"
640f86076440c21c48be540bcdd4c428698442be: Swedish inflation has thus fallen below the Riksbank's target of two percent, which may have an impact on future interest rate announcements. According to Frida Bratt, it is above all the strengthened krona that contributed to imports becoming cheaper and thus pushed inflation down. The Riksbank's next step - I think this suggests that the next step will be a decrease rather than an increase. There has been talk of an increase, but now we see that inflation is coming quite far. It comes below the inflation target of two percent, says Frida Bratt. She believes that low inflation partly shows that growth has not picked up, which may lead to the Riksbank wanting to support the economy by lowering interest rates. At the same time, it may take some time before a possible reduction takes place. - Even if the next step could be a reduction, it could take a while. You want to wait and see: Will growth pick up in the Swedish economy and thus also inflation? Inflation measure in focus CPIF excluding energy (KPIF-XE) is often used to give a clearer picture of the underlying inflation, as energy prices are difficult to influence. If energy prices are included, inflation lands at two percent. - You would like to look at what is moving underneath if you ignore the energy prices and count them out, very relevant to look at, says Frida Bratt.

fa446b50784abe177e92d90cb362ee24548f9a6c: Snow chaos continues in Skåne - many accidents last night
6ea198ebcd748223163973ab6134cbe55cb07452:
SMHI has previously issued an orange warning over south-eastern Scania, which is valid until Friday afternoon. It has been snowing and blowing heavily in several places, causing traffic delays.  During Thursday evening and the night of Friday, the rescue service dealt with around 50 incidents in the area. Of these, around 20 traffic accidents have occurred, but no serious incidents have been reported. 

- It has been a little more than usual, but relatively calm considering the storm, says Nadja Hellsten, alarm and control officer at the South Rescue Service. According to Nadja Hellsten, there have been an unusually high number of traffic accidents, but no one has been seriously injured.  - We have had about 20 traffic accidents, but none of a serious nature, says Nadja Hellsten.  Several accidents occurred on the Öresund Bridge, where slippery road conditions and strong winds caused cars to spin or drive into the center railing, reports P4 Malmöhus.  Stop on E4 There is also a stop on E4 in the southbound direction after Markaryd södra, after a truck drove into the center guardrail, reports P4 Kronoberg.  In addition to the orange warning, SMHI has also issued a yellow warning for southern and central Scania. Both warnings are in effect until 2pm on Friday. No injuries have been reported.

1bb5ca8fa961c6b1b84819b414c648730f79379e: Sweden gives 10 million to democracy fighters in Iran
866afb6f09c06d9ff486f6589f717a901c7acf42:
The government condemns the deadly violence against peaceful protesters and the widespread, arbitrary detentions that took place in the wake of the protests.  As a clear indication, the Iranian ambassador has been summoned to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, where Sweden underlined the right of the Iranian people to express their views. Support via Sida - recipients secret The new support is to be channeled via Sida and directed to human rights activists, democracy advocates and other actors who work for increased freedom of expression in Iran. The government does not want to go into exactly who gets a share of the money. - For security reasons, we cannot go into details about which people or organizations it is about. But like all aid, we have very strict regulations to ensure that the money ends up right, says Dousa. The support can be used, among other things, to strengthen the security of people who peacefully work for democracy and human rights, says Minister for Aid Benjamin Dousa (M) to TV4 Nyheterna. Pressure against Iran to increase At the same time, Sweden wants to see continued heavy international pressure against the Iranian regime. The government supports new EU sanctions against regime representatives who were involved in the deadly violence against protesters.  Sweden also welcomes that the EU countries have now agreed to list the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps as terrorists - a demand that the government has pushed for for a long time with the support of a unanimous Riksdag. - No one can do everything, but everyone can do something. We are at the forefront now in Europe and hope that more countries will follow with similar support, says Dousa.

The government's announcement comes at the same time as the protests in Iran continue to be met with harsh reprisals from the regime. According to the government, the support is a clear signal that Sweden stands behind the Iranian people in the fight for freedom, democracy and human rights.

185803ab417d16f56f000488e9c695096b65beab: So many Swedes want nuclear weapons: "Surprising support"
5780d4af76c2495fff85effaee247e5cb38b0564: After Donald Trump threatened to take Greenland militarily, fundamental questions have been raised about how Europe should protect its borders. Such as whether it is still possible to trust the USA, or possibly it is time for Sweden to build up its own nuclear deterrent. - Not to show the power like the USA, that we have this, and sort of show the shoulders and muscles. But as a defense for a country that has fought for so many years to become the strong Sweden that it is right now, says Marya Osman. - That can be an argument, but at the same time we have allies who have nuclear weapons. So nuclear weapons should deter, and it won't if everyone has them, says Roger Wilhelmsson. Higher support than expected In a survey conducted by Novus with 1,007 respondents, 68 percent recently said no to Sweden acquiring its own nuclear weapons to increase its security. But 17 per cent positive was still higher support than expected, according to the head of research for the FOI's nuclear analysis programme. - People's concerns are expressed in this, and it's not entirely unreasonable. That doesn't mean the doors to everyone are open to anything right now, so to speak. But it is probably a reflection of the fact that we have a challenging security policy situation where people are willing to reconsider previous positions, says Karl Sörenson, head of FOI research. At the same time, new nuclear weapons programs have a high price. According to Sörenson, Europe should primarily deepen cooperation with France's and Great Britain's already existing programs, but primarily continue to build up its conventional defense capabilities. Difficult situation for the USA Sörenson also points out that, despite Trump's actions, the USA continues to guarantee NATO's nuclear deterrent, and preferably does not want to see a too strong Europe there. - The spread effect that would then occur might not only be in Europe but contagion and spread further in the world, it would create a situation that is much more complicated even for the United States to handle, if many countries in the world acquire nuclear weapons. So for the US it is probably in many ways better to have it that way

Unscientific treatment methods Cold facts have revealed, among other things, that Eliva sold unscientific treatment methods and failed to report medical injuries to Lex Maria. A health care scandal Health Minister Elisabet Lann calls what happened at Eliva a major health care scandal and during the meeting took up two measures to prevent it from happening again: Firstly, it should be easier for patients to determine which treatment methods are approved by offering them knowledge support. Elisabet Lann further believes that Kalla fakta's disclosure has also brought up the issue of licensing requirements for private healthcare companies. An investigation into this is ongoing. - This would mean that everyone who is currently a care provider would have to be approved in order to get this permit. It is a way to get rid of unscrupulous actors, she believes. Elisabet Lann reacts strongly to the fact that Eliva has not made a single patient-related Lex Maria report in five years despite repeated serious incidents and care injuries at the clinic. 0ea5e01d5a32d7eb9973e5ed43e5ee15d3a55457: The municipality's proposal: Sex at work - as health care
1f9c016aec3f584050ab947e40263042b047c8f3: The proposal, which has attracted a lot of attention, means that intimate activities can count as wellness, something SVT Dalarna was the first to report. The Center Party in Älvdalen, which is behind the proposal, writes, among other things, in a motion: "The wellness hour must be used for any health-promoting activity, including voluntary and consenting intimate togetherness" They are also clear that this must take place in ways that respect legislation and the work environment. Several politicians in the municipal board supported the proposal and hope that the initiative will lead to both better health and more residents. But Suzann Larsdotter sees both opportunities and risks. Voluntariness and integrity in focus According to Larsdotter, it can be positive to raise questions about sexual health and intimacy, especially since many couples find it difficult to find time for closeness in everyday life. - In my clinical everyday life, many people find it difficult to find time, so maybe this could make it easier, she says in Efter fem. At the same time, she warns that political initiatives in the area risk becoming normative and putting pressure on residents to have children. - It can become a bit problematic when the municipality somewhere puts pronatalist pressure on the population and somehow urges that it is an obligation to have children, says Suzann Larsdotter. "A way to get some attention" Larsdotter believes that the proposal is primarily a way to create debate and visibility ahead of the upcoming election year. - I think this was a way to get some attention to politics. They got quite a lot of media attention through this proposal, she says. She also points out that there are practical and ethical issues to consider, and that employers must protect the privacy of their employees. - It should be about privacy and maybe it shouldn't be personnel policy at work, says Suzann Larsdotter.

According to information to TV4 Nyheterna, the authority is suspected of covering up nearly 200 possible environmental crimes by not reporting the incidents to the police. The majority of cases are linked to LKAB, SSAB and Boliden Mineral. TV4 Nyheterna has now spoken to employees at the County Administrative Board in Norrbotten. - We have long been very frustrated about this very thing, that you don't file a police report when it comes to environmental crimes. There are several of us who are very critical of how the County Administrative Board handles suspected environmental crimes, says a person at the authority. The suspicions of malfeasance at the County Administrative Board came to light when the police received a report about one of Sweden's largest diesel spills - just over three years after it occurred. In connection with that investigation, the police discovered another 200 unreported suspected environmental crimes. - It should be enough that the County Administrative Board has a suspicion of environmental crime, then a report must be made. Then the police can investigate whether it is or not. We should not sit at the County Board and investigate whether it might be an environmental crime or not. And it takes a long time. In some cases the police report is not submitted, in other cases it has taken two or three years to submit a police report, says an employee to TV4 Nyheterna. "Nothing happens" Several people with insight tell TV4 Nyheterna that the County Administrative Board's long delay in reporting suspected environmental crimes, when it is reported, among other things complicates the police's preliminary investigation and that the police are then several years behind in the investigation. - Partly that. But even then, these activities that caused the environmental crime are allowed to continue and continue to pollute or whatever it is they are doing. In that way, the County Administrative Board becomes complicit in making things worse, says an informant at the authority. 6219e9614bf1ea2e9d13c7dd85a462291cf55626: The find in customs: Ancient space rock - disguised as a garden ornament
cc398c98a4678ddfd7e9a489e0fe7bebc9fc80ed: Russian customs authorities have stopped an unusual smuggling attempt: a huge fragment of a meteorite that was to be brought to Britain, disguised as a garden decoration. This was stated by the Federal Customs Service on Thursday. The gray space rock, which weighs over 2.5 tons, was discovered during a routine inspection of a sea container in the port of St. Petersburg.  In the export documents, the cargo was described as a garden sculpture, but when customs officials took a closer look, it quickly became clear that something was not right - neither with the object's origin nor its true value. Cargo worth SEK 38 million The fragment is believed to come from the world-famous Aletai meteorite, one of the largest known iron meteorites on Earth.  In a video released by the authorities, customs personnel can be seen breaking open a wooden box and exposing the massive stone, with a rough, gray and uneven surface. According to Russian customs authorities, the meteorite fragment could be worth around 323 million rubles – equivalent to almost 38 million kroner. 4.5 billion years old Who is behind the smuggling attempt has not been made public, but authorities confirm that the destination was Britain. A criminal investigation has now been opened by prosecutors. The Aletai meteorite was discovered in western China back in 1898 and is estimated to be at least 4.5 billion years old – almost as old as the solar system itself.  Scientists have long warned about the growing trade in meteorites, which are often invaluable to research and can provide important clues about the early history of the solar system.

7a1c7a6790b9d9540a64ba8c5ccfc57e331cab45: SAS plane about to take off from taxiway - expert: "Very serious"
ccaf7239c717ffe8e6da1a61b0cd2ed19149f65b: On Thursday evening, SAS flight SK2590 rolled out towards the runway at Brussels airport with destination Copenhagen.  The aircraft began to accelerate, reaching about 200 kilometers per hour, according to FlightRadar.  Suddenly the pilots realized they were on the taxiway, the road used to get out to the runway. They were forced to cross, veered left and ended up in the grass. - It is very serious, says aviation expert and former SAS pilot Björn Lundström. He believes that it could have been much, much worse. - A car could have come out on this taxiway or another plane or other traffic, he says and adds: - Then they would have had a collision. Deadly examples In commercial traffic, it is very rare for aircraft to take off from the taxiway. But there are examples. Last year, a Boeing 737-800 was aborted from takeoff after air traffic control at Orlando airport discovered they were on the taxiway.  Björn Lundström also raises a tragic example from 2000. At the airport in Singapore, a passenger plane bound for Los Angeles began to take off from a closed runway.  The plane collided with construction machinery and equipment and 83 people died.  Swedes on board Several KD politicians were on the plane.  - As I understand it, it would have been difficult to stop the plane if we had driven five more seconds, says Dan-Ove Marcelind (KD) to Expressen. According to him, the staff was stressed because the flight was heavily delayed.  - Stress is a risk factor for a pilot, you know that, so you should be extra vigilant, says Björn Lundström. He is surprised by the incident. The taxiway is marked with completely different lighting and signs compared to the runways.  Björn Lundström also says that the aircraft probably had a map in the cockpit with the exact position.  He believes that the responsibility lies with the pilots. - You have to question yourself all the time.

dc04d224be3d3e9c13115dc848bcbcdad8967dad: Was surreptitiously filmed naked for years - denied compensation: "Unfathomable"
828973fe68d7055134bdbc4aeafae5547388394b: A former school employee in Haninge municipality was charged in September with sexual harassment after filming 50 girls naked, including in changing rooms. The suspected abuses took place between 2009 and 2013, and at the end of May last year, over 160 former students at the school where the teacher worked received letters from the police stating that they are plaintiffs in the investigation.  Now the Södertörn district court announces that the prosecution will not be tried, because the teacher was convicted in 2023 by the Svea Court of Appeal for several cases of child pornography crimes. The penalty was three years and six months in prison - a sentence he is still serving. - The films in this case were included in the previous indictment, but the plaintiffs were then unidentified. If the prosecutor had wanted to test how it happened when the films were recorded, this would have been investigated before charges were brought for the possession of the films, says councilor Fredrik Nydén, who was the court's chairman.  The district court has also ruled that the surreptitious filming, which the man admitted, does not fall under the criminal classification of sexual harassment, which was required for the plaintiff to receive damages. This means that all claims for damages have been rejected. "Hard to find words" Hanna Charlton is one of the 50 affected girls. She is 22 years old today. - That the verdict resulted in zero extended sentence and zero kroner in compensation to the victims is completely unimaginable to me, given what he has actually done to us over so many years. I have difficulty finding words for this, she says to TV4 Nyheterna. d381e110963e6a5035a8e5f15fd7cfc65d6ab391: The flu is turning up again after a sharp decline
810675d1929593eb0362a35f2b71d8fbae2e9090: This year's flu season peaked at the beginning of January and then declined sharply, figures from the Public Health Agency show.  But now the trend has turned.  The number of confirmed cases and patients in intensive care is increasing. - We'll see if it's just a temporary bump in the curve and it goes down in the future or if there will be an increase again, says Magnus Gisslén. Klara Sondén, deputy state epidemiologist at the Public Health Agency says that the rise is quite expected after the Christmas holidays. - We are all on site in schools and workplaces. You have many contacts, so it is easy for the infection to spread from person to person. The Public Health Agency predicts that the spread of influenza will continue in the coming months.  It is the new aggressive mutation H3N2 that dominates the spread of infection right now.   - It can escape our immune system a little easier than other variants precisely because it has changed so much. The effect of vaccines is also slightly worse on this variant. Winter sickness on the rise As far as winter sickness is concerned, the peak has not been reached. The spread of infection is on the rise and the number of confirmed cases at the Public Health Agency is higher compared to the same period last year.  Everything indicates that the spread of infection continues to increase, it will take some time before the curves start to turn downwards. - You can count on it to increase now for a number of weeks until March, says Magnus Gisslén. The Swedish Public Health Agency urges you to wash your hands thoroughly and stay home if you are sick.  If you have symptoms of a respiratory infection, remember to show special consideration to the people who are at risk of becoming seriously ill. This applies even if your symptoms are mild.

d9957e34911d150d111b23d2fa7c9821a83a29cb: The expert explains: This is how the pension is affected by your vaping
c8deb7947e8201f0f91891d22738e5156006b3c9: The fact that you lose income by babbling is perhaps not so strange. Money from Försäkringskassan covers just under 80 percent of the salary and there is also a cap on how much money you can get. But for the vast majority of people, vaping does not have a very large impact on the future pension, according to the Pensions Authority, which believes that it is sometimes presented as vaping can be a big sink. Vabb affects the pension to a very small extent. The allowance from Försäkringskassan is pensionable, although it may be slightly lower than the salary. In addition, the employer usually continues to pay into the occupational pension, which is therefore not affected, says Monica Zettervall at the Swedish Pensions Agency. Part-time a criminal According to the authority, it is a matter of relatively few kroner a month in reduced pension calculated over an entire working life. The pension system has built-in airbags which mean that parenthood affects the pension very little, says Monica Zettervall. What rather affects the pension is, among other things, how one chooses to share the parental allowance and the unpaid work in the home, for which women take responsibility to a greater extent. Part-time work is a factor that affects the long term. If you work part-time for more than four years when the children are small, it can start to be felt in the pension. During the first four years, there is pension entitlement for childhood years in the general pension system, which largely compensates for the loss of income.  Small difference Generally, high income earners in the private sector are affected more than those with low and medium incomes in the state and municipality, according to Zettervall.  The call from the Swedish Pensions Authority is not to worry too much about the pension when you are at home with a sick child. Most people who open their orange envelope won't see much of a difference because you've vacillated. I think it creates a lot of unnecessary anxiety, says Monica Zettervall.

Maternity care is now at the center of the political debate. During the latest party leader debate, KD leader Ebba Busch attacked Magdalena Andersson (S) on the issue of maternity care and women's health. - If you compare the social democratic efforts during the whole eight years, they still do not reach what has been achieved during the last three years, said Ebba Busch, among other things. Tidöpartierna invests on a national level One of the crown jewels of Tidöpartierna's investments is a national plan for pregnancy, childbirth and aftercare. Recently, the government issued a press release stating that it is now making a "major investment" in maternity care and women's health. Among other things, it concerns targeted government support to the regions of around SEK 1 billion. But in previous years, the corresponding money bag in the state budget has been around SEK 1.6 billion. Health Minister Elisabet Lann points out that the government is putting money into a number of areas related to women's health, in addition to maternity care. - We are allocating SEK 200 million to care for victims of sexual violence. We are also putting half a billion extra into cancer healthcare, where breast cancer is the most common form of cancer. It is also great means of shortening the queues for prolapse operations. It is something that only women demand and need, she says. S criticizes the government for fiddling with numbers But the Social Democrats in the Stockholm region are now storming against the government's measures - which they consider to be fiddling with numbers. - The Swedish healthcare system has gone through a national healthcare crisis with great notice around the country. We know that it is the healthcare staff who are the most important resource in healthcare in order for us to shorten care queues and provide care as needed. Together, they make up the largest industry currently operating in the country, according to the president. "Aviation is one of the promising investment areas in Ukraine. 97d6fb1de3ca90111bfe29673f851fbf0f8a4d74: Several fatal accidents in avalanches: "Mode to be extra careful"
03d5cad54cc679077f9a7f9e74d7de73aaac5dd8: Since the start of this year's ski season, more than 50 people have died in avalanche accidents in the Alps, according to the European Avalanche Warning Services (EAWS). Last Saturday, four people died in two separate avalanche accidents in Italy. The reason behind the fatal accidents can be several, and the snow-poor winter that prevails in large parts of the Alps is likely one of them. Less snow means that the snow is less compacted, and in addition weak layers of snow can remain for several weeks. - They are difficult for the common man to follow - and also for professionals, says Petter Palmgren, avalanche expert at the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency. A catalyst for accidents In addition to weather, a large proportion of accidents can be explained by the human factor. The majority of avalanches that occur are triggered naturally, but the avalanches that lead to deaths are almost exclusively triggered by humans, says Petter Palmgren. Statistically, accidents increase the more people are in the ski systems, and therefore the combination of newly fallen snow and snow-poor winters is a bit of a catalyst for accidents. - When a little snow finally falls, many people are starved for good skiing. Large avalanches are then quite common. Until the beginning of February in the previous two seasons, a total of 28 and 30 people respectively lost their lives in avalanche accidents in the Alps, according to figures from EAWS. This year, there have thus been almost twice as many fatal accidents within the same time period. - It's probably quite a lot for the time of year, says Petter Palmgren. "It's not a good idea to go off-piste" According to Petter Palmgren, off-piste skiers, top tourers and to some extent climbers are responsible for almost all avalanche-related deaths. Especially off-piste skating is popular among Swedes, and the sports holiday is just around the corner. - It is time to be extra careful if you go off-piste or go on a trip in the Alps during the sports holiday. These are risky activities that require preparation. Read up on the weather conditions and forecasts, and think about what you can and can't handle. ab207eda691bfea1d776f4767fb1c5b8c0900466: Far-right graffiti in Stockholm's schools has increased by 140 percent in the past three years, according to Stockholm city statistics reported by P4 Stockholm. At Skarpnäck's elementary school, racist stickers and swastikas have been discovered. The school management has urged parents to talk to their children about what happened. According to Christer Mattsson, researcher and expert on right-wing extremism and violence at the University of Gothenburg, the increase is neither unique to Stockholm nor a new phenomenon. - The behavior with doodles is something that goes in waves, he says. "Generates a curiosity" He links the development to the attention that has been around new far-right groups in recent years. - I would interpret it as being related to the attention that has been around new extreme right-wing groups, not least the active clubs, which in turn generate a curiosity and then you move that aesthetic out to the outside world. Similar graffiti waves have been seen before in Sweden, according to Mattsson. He points to the 1960s and the so-called squint epidemic. - The first wave was named the swastika epidemic where swastikas start to be scribbled everywhere and actually led to the first school effort in Sweden to raise awareness about the Holocaust. Today, doodling is not always about clear swastikas. Instead, more subtle symbols and number combinations are often used. - In a subculture, you would like to have symbols that you in that culture understand, but which are more difficult to understand for others. It creates a sense of belonging. Nazi memes An example is the number 14. - It is from an old Nazi slogan, it becomes 14 words, and this has been around for a long time. It is something that recurs and is reproduced in different contexts. At the same time, Mattsson believes that graffiti in a school environment is often connected to a wider exposure, above all digitally. - What is much more constant and at a much higher level, are the memes that appear on social media. Then you take the step Facing the messages repeatedly can have consequences, both for them

4267bd277b81e19018dd255382127170c262e271: The DNA solution came too late - the killer who got away
25526f01b56cfab83dd60f2f6f4fd2b15b62c024:
On October 13, 2005, Marie Johansson was found dead in the fabric store Stuvkällaren on Kyrkogatan in central Gothenburg. Early on, investigators had both DNA and witness information about a woman in a black jacket and pink sweatpants, but despite extensive efforts, the killer went free for almost two decades. - One week, then it's solved, they said. A week passed, then two weeks passed, then a month passed, then three months passed, then six months passed, then a year, says Marie's sister Birgitta Borén in The Murder of Marie - that's why the killer goes free on TV4 PLAY The DNA finding was decisive The police were convinced for a long time that the case would be solved quickly. The coroner found clear repulsive injuries and the perpetrator had left traces of blood after cutting himself during the attack. Anders Eriksson is involved when the police in the West start a new cold case group in 2016 and the murder of Marie is one of the cases that the group takes on. - In terms of investigation, it is not a complicated matter in view of the forensic evidence. If we find the person who has deposited his DNA through blood, then it is the perpetrator, he says.  The big turnaround Despite phantom images, surveillance footage and tips from the public, the breakthrough was delayed. Only in 2022, when a woman in her 40s was busted after a minor theft, was her DNA matched to the findings from the murder scene. The police were sure they had found Marie's killer.  But the joy was short-lived. The woman was only 17 years old at the time of the murder, and the statute of limitations for murder of minors was then 15 years. The DNA meeting came about two years too late - and no trial could ever be held. - It's bad for everyone. There is no winner in that it has turned out the way it has with these rules, says Anders Eriksson. Sentenced for new crimes The woman who the police are sure is guilty of the murder was recently sentenced to prison for aggravated theft against the elderly in her work in home care. But she has never spoken publicly about Marie's murder.

5cf812e0fa78fbf5d698b3820397c8fe0011b956: On Wednesday, SVT Norrbotten reported that the steel group Stegra has unpaid invoices of several hundred million. A day later, Otto Gernandt left his role as the company's CFO to take on an advisory role. The announcement from the green steel company is ominous, says Ossi Pesämaa, assistant professor of accounting and management at Luleå University of Technology. - Key people abandon ship, it's quite critical. A total of around SEK 70 billion has been invested in the green steel project. As a comparison, industry colleague SSAB's has a market capitalization of just over SEK 76 billion. - Stegra's loans are thus almost as large as one of Sweden's largest industrial groups. Add to that that Stegra is not even fully built, and in such a complex industrial plant there will be many elements and uncertainties even after completion, says Ossi Pesämaa. May need to double the loans According to Ossi Pesämaa, Stegra's facility is about 60 percent complete. Construction costs have skyrocketed and port construction has been put on hold. The financiers turn a blind eye. - Now you have applied for ten billion more, but if you are only halfway there, maybe another 70 billion is required - and maybe a little more. Where are they going to find that money now that the trust capital is at the bottom?, asks Ossi Pesämaa. Stegra's situation is increasingly reminiscent of bankrupt Northvolt. Stegra is structured in the same way and, just like Northvolt, has been able to show order books as security for financing. Now they are burdened - just as the battery law did - by multibillion-dollar debts and a trust that has run to rock bottom. - I think it is very likely that this will fall apart. The problem: Optimism bias Steel production worldwide accounts for around eight percent of global carbon dioxide emissions. In Sweden, the figure is around ten percent. It is therefore no wonder that green investments such as Stegra have gained popularity. In working condition, it would be a hyper-modern company with doubled steel production with non-existent colds
94d0f6a865fb4cbc179c40950431afb1224989fa: Mikaela's OCD got worse when she had children
a93261280c375c14237eab4daf78c434ae1bf775:
Already as a child, Mikaela had intrusive thoughts, but it was after she became a mother in 2021 that everything got worse. She describes how the anxiety around sleep and worry about harming her child took over her whole existence.

- I could only think if I had hurt him without remembering it. The thoughts took up all my waking hours, says Mikaela. Didn't dare to be alone with her child In the end Mikaela was on sick leave. She sought help in the psychiatric ward when she felt she no longer wanted to live.

- I was afraid of hurting my child and did not dare to be alone with him. I wanted someone else to always be there, she says. The turnaround came after she was admitted to psychiatry last fall. A new medication allowed her to relax for the first time in a long time.

- Without the medications, I don't think I would have been sitting here. They enabled me to adopt CBT and learn to manage my thoughts, says Mikaela. Support from other mothers Mikaela has chosen to be open about her OCD and received strong support from others, especially mothers who recognized her story.

- The guilt and shame is great when it comes to one's children. But many people have contacted me and said that they experience the same thing, she says. Today, Mikaela works part-time and can be with her son without the anxiety taking over.

- I enjoy more, plan things and can be present. Before, I was just trying to survive – now I'm living, says Mikaela Eklund. Effective treatment is available Christian Rück, senior physician and professor at the Karolinska Institutet, emphasizes that there is help available.

- There is good hope for good help, he says.

45be0c91a3511ba5f67e32761434bb5677de7371: The weather causes chaos in the regular traffic - buses break down from the cold
2a5c49020007bfb2990a08b3f9802b38c27689cc:
This winter has been marked by storms, snowfall and low temperatures, which has led to extensive traffic disruptions. Several bus companies have been forced to cancel trips when the vehicles could not cope with the cold. Among other things, travelers in West Sweden, Skellefteå, Luleå and in other places have been affected.

In Östersund, the temperature has periodically approached minus 30 degrees. This has led to it becoming too cold inside the buses for both drivers and passengers, which has forced companies to cancel departures. - It's not good. I think that as a traveler you can make high demands that the buses can handle the cold and not be cancelled. And that they must also manage to keep the timetable, says Christina Hellblom in Östersund.

Simon Dickens, site manager at Vy bus in Östersund, regrets the situation. - Yes, it is regrettable, above all for the travellers, he says. Challenges for the bus companies The question of why the buses cannot cope with the cold comes up frequently. - Yes, one might think so. But we don't have bus manufacturing up here in Östersund and have to buy in buses that are manufactured in other places. And we have chosen the best buses available, in our opinion, says Simon Dickens.

He emphasizes that the company does its utmost to avoid canceled tours. - We do everything we can so that it doesn't have to happen, says Simon Dickens, site manager at Vy bus in Östersund.

e855cb5dc7bcfabb119c4381417d819fb5d8430c: The country's poorest are used as cannon fodder in the war
e812bc53c4f6b4454ab633f75be642da4a884a54: The BBC's Russian editors, together with the news organization Mediazona and a team of volunteers, have analyzed Russian soldiers who died in the war in Ukraine.   According to open sources, 173,477 Russians have been confirmed killed in the war since the full-scale invasion in 2022, but the figure is estimated to be up to 385,500 people.  There is a clear pattern among the fallen; the poorer, the greater the risk of dying. Renat Mukmenov from the city of Chita in southeastern Russia was in a deep debt crisis, when the regime increased the regional one-off payment for signing contracts with the army from 250,000 rubles to 400,000 rubles, equivalent to about 50,000 kroner. Renat Mukmenov was sent to the front in the summer of 2024, and in mid-August communication ceased. - I suspect that the number of people considering signing a contract and going to war will only increase as the Russian economy slows down and wage increases slow down, says Alexander Kolyandr, visiting researcher at the Center for European Policy Analysis to the BBC.  15 times higher chance of dying The area of ​​Zabaikalsky kray, where Renat Mukmenov came from, is one of the poorest regions in Russia and, according to the analysis, has one of the highest rates of fatalities per capita. Residents of the region are 15 times more likely to die in the war than residents of Moscow. - Calm in the capitals and the North Caucasus has traditionally been very important for maintaining social order and stability in Russia, says Alexander Kolyandr. There are a couple of exceptions to the analysis. In some of Russia's poorest regions – Chechnya, Ingushetia and Karachay-Cherkessia – deaths per capita are on a par with the rich cities of Moscow and Saint Petersburg. Sent to the front instead of trial Over half of all dead are voluntary, mobilized or convicted criminals from correctional facilities. People who had no connection to the army before the outbreak of war. Defendants in criminal cases have fallen among the dead, compared to a year ago.

The high pressure literally pushes down the water, which is pushed out of the Baltic Sea. In Stockholm, the water level is now the lowest in at least 15 years, according to SMHI.  17th century wreck visible The weather phenomenon has caused the Orlogsfartyget at Kastellholmen in Stockholm to look forward. The shipwreck from the 17th century is 40 meters long and usually lies below the surface of the water. The ship has not been wrecked, but sunk on the spot, which means that the ship is very intact.  - When it was no longer worth repairing the ships, the navy reused the material and sunk them. It's a cool phenomenon, instead of using new wood, they use old ship scrap, says Jim Hansson, marine archaeologist at the Wreck Museum to Dagens Nyheter. But the low water levels have also caused it in its parts. Around 20 piers have been pulled into the Stockholm archipelago because the boats cannot dock. It is also difficult for the boats to dock at Strömkajen because the angle of the gangway is too steep. - Absolutely, it causes it, we have some piers where the boats cannot dock, says Helene Jakobsson, business area manager for sea traffic. But boat traffic is among the lowest of the year and Helene Jakobsson is not particularly concerned about the inhabitants of the archipelago. - There is an awareness of the power of the weather when you live out in the archipelago, she says. The pressure will release next week The long-term high pressure over Sweden will slowly but surely move away and turn into a low pressure. - The water level looks like it will drop another couple of days ahead, then turn around in the middle of the week, when the weather will be more low-pressure based according to the forecast, says Madeleine Westin. She is one of the few children evacuated from Gaza for care. Right now, several different organizations believe that between 18-20,000 patients need to leave the Gaza Strip to receive better care. Last Monday, the Rafah border between Gaza and Egypt was opened and many hoped to be able to go to a better hospital outside Gaza.  But the process is both slow and complicated, which has meant that only around 100 patients plus their relatives were able to leave in just over a week. The patients in Amman have gone via the Kerem Shalom crossing, through Israel to Jordan. - The process is extremely slow, difficult and cumbersome. The king of Jordan has said that we will help 2,000 children but so far we have only managed to get 650 children out. I'm afraid that many will die because the wait is so long, says Fawzi Al-Hammouri doctor Specialty hospital. War injuries and a long wait The patients who have come to Amman are a mixture of children with war injuries, cancer or who need internal medicine.  Inside the physiotherapy, we meet the sisters Sarah, 15 and Saraa, 17. They were both badly injured when the house fell on them after a bomb attack in northern Gaza. Saraa was injured in the knees and operated on in Gaza and can now walk relatively well. But Sarah, who injured her neck and spine, could not get help on the spot. - I couldn't move my arms or legs. But it took 6 months before I could be evacuated from Gaza. Here in Amman they operated on me and through physiotherapy I have regained some of my strength, she says. Both sisters study remotely and want to become doctors and physiotherapists. - After what we have been through, we want to use the experience gained to help others, says Saraa. 10-year-old Rama will probably stay in Amman for a long time. Both her mother and uncles have children
