- You must not give the appearance that you are selling something on other premises than what it is. You must not say that I am selling for a certain purpose when it is a completely different purpose that I am selling for. Then you mislead consumers, says consumer advisor Maria Wiezell. The sellers lie about sales In several of the reports that TV4 Nyheterna has seen, it is described how the sellers state that the money from the sale goes to, for example, the class fund or savings for a driver's license.

But according to the reports, this is not true.

One of the notifications comes from a high school teacher in southern Sweden. The teacher writes that students at the school have told about the scheme and is sharply critical of the company's methods.

"It feels disgusting that they partly target minors and use their desire to earn a little money to cheat private individuals out of money and extract an outrageous profit through this". Should be investigated further The approach is not completely new, but according to Maria Wiezell, the procedure should be examined more closely.

- Around 30 reports should be an incentive for the Swedish Consumer Agency to look into this, especially when children are also being exploited.

At the same time, she points out that the responsibility for reporting misleading sales often lies with consumers - something that can be problematic. In many cases, they do not know that they have been deceived. Who is responsible? According to Maria Wiezell, the responsibility clearly lies with the employers, which she believes is problematic from several perspectives.

In total, they and the dog Aloka have walked over 370 miles before they now reach the American capital. - It's a bit like the great elk migration to follow these monks. What they create around them is very special, says Håkan Friedel, who is a Buddhist. Accidents and challenges on the way The walk has not been without difficulties. In Texas, a car crashed into the caravan, forcing one of the monks to have a leg amputated. In South Carolina, the dog Aloka needed surgery before he could continue. Despite the cold of the American winter, the monks have continued, often barefoot and sometimes without even lying down when sleeping. - These are very advanced donuts as far as I understand. So they take on a special exercise for themselves, for their own sake, to be able to reach deeper into themselves, says Håkan Friedel. Great commitment and meetings with politicians Thousands of people have followed the monks along the way and millions have become involved online. During the walk, they have stopped to talk to both ordinary people and politicians. - There are a lot of conflicts in America. It feels very right that the monks are out walking and talking to people. They stop and share what they have with them, says Håkan Friedel. The monks will participate in several events in Washington. They also plan to submit a request to Congress for the Buddha's birthday to be officially observed, although they themselves emphasize that the most important thing is meeting people. - Of course, the big overarching goal has been to walk for world peace, but it is undeniably the case, as a monk put it, that the goal has also been to get people along the way to stop and get distraction from the problems that weigh on them in everyday life, says Filip Jacobson, foreign correspondent.

f46dbfd6486047fb8e842c4f3c9e932c9e3ff873: Clara has a phobia of food: "Sheer horror"
0c12a947851499cb79e190c13bb6fc322e325d2c: Arfid affects an estimated 1–5 percent of the population. Unlike other eating disorders, Arfid is not about body ideals or weight, but about a strong reluctance or fear of food, often linked to taste, smell or texture. Klara Edlund, psychologist and researcher, emphasizes that Arfid is not about being picky or spoiled. - This is about a neurobiologically rooted eating disorder. It's about a strong inability to eat enough, which means you end up with both energy and nutritional deficiencies, says Klara Edlund. "It comes physically from within" Many people with Arfid describe a strong fear of negative consequences of eating, such as vomiting or choking. For Clara Lager, the fear has sometimes led to panic attacks and severe anxiety, even though she tries to have a positive attitude. - When that reflex comes and that discomfort comes, it's like I have no power over it. It comes physically from within. It's not something I get for myself, but I want to be able to eat like everyone else, she says. Treatment with CBT Klara Edlund urges you to seek help via a health centre, BVC or school nurse if you suspect Arfid in yourself or your child. Despite the fact that knowledge of Arfid is low, there is help to be had. Clara Lager herself has undergone cognitive behavioral therapy, CBT, which helped her approach new foods step by step. - It's about gaining an understanding of how you function, which foods are the easiest to approach, which situations would have made the biggest difference in everyday life, says Clara Lager.

606b17fd29c68511e0c912a1c9211b0a07d36aa2: Gangster arrested after sabotage - had the Russian coat of arms on him
141a5f3127f86e751a459a957a894f2fdec73cf2: The 30-year-old was detained last weekend by the Västmanland district court. During the hearing, the man admitted to the crime of sabotage and agreed to be detained. - He admits that he was there, that's what I can say, says District Attorney Magnus Möller, who has the case on his table. Arrested on the run The incident took place at 02.30 on January 30. The police were then alerted to Mälarenergi's facility in Västerås. The power at the Hässlö waterworks had been cut off after a sabotage against the electrical installations inside the protected area. A police patrol was able to quickly track down the saboteur and arrested the 30-year-old when he tried to run from the scene. According to information to TV4 Nyheterna, the man was wearing a cap with the Russian coat of arms when he was arrested. - We do not go into more detail about what information we have or what our cooperation with the Police Authority looks like in individual cases, says Jonathan Svensson, press spokesperson at the Security Police, Säpo. Unknown motive The 30-year-old man has appeared in the legal system since a young age and has a long criminal record with several serious crimes. He has been sentenced together with, among others, a well-known leader of a notorious criminal network and has been involved in high-profile gang cases. Säpo has previously come out and warned of increased threats of sabotage from Russia. However, the prosecutor does not want to comment on the information that the detainee had the Russian state coat of arms. - There is preliminary investigation secrecy, so I cannot go into details. I must point out that there will be a preliminary investigation protocol where it will appear, says Magnus Möller. According to the prosecutor, no motive behind the nocturnal sabotage has yet been discovered. - So far we don't have that. But he will be interrogated once more and it may become clearer then, says Magnus Möller. "Very serious" According to Mälarenergi, the sabotage did not lead to any impact on the quality of the drinking water. - But due to the power outage at the Hässlö waterworks on the night of January 30, the waterworks could not supply drinking water
4923a8cb079c5d82c51dd339f02e7ebe2f5d8cba: Tried to mislabel expired candy - five tons seized
402332fe1356aa00d70d52264090d5dab646d6ea: When Malmö city inspectors recently visited a wholesale company, 5.2 tons of approximately one-year-old candy were discovered that were about to be relabeled with new best-before dates. This is reported by the news agency Siren. Two people who were working on packaging goods in connection with ten pallets of candy boxes immediately left the premises when the inspectors showed up, according to the environmental administration.  - We are doing outreach to inventory premises, including in this area, which is densely packed with wholesalers. When two people stick out immediately when we arrive, it of course arouses our interest, says unit manager Caroline Tandefelt to Nyhetsbyrån Siren. On a follow-up visit, those in charge stated that the candy had accidentally not been disposed of. "In the premises there were prepared packing surfaces, empty new cartons, unused bags for repackaging, tape, sealing machine and solvents in the form of acetone and nail polish remover with the aim of removing labels and erasing the best before date", writes the environmental administration in its decision. Cat chasing mice The spaces in the premises were also dirty and unhygienic. Among other things, a cat had been placed there to keep mice and vermin away. "There was a litter box in the toilet and cat food was stored in the fridge," the decision states. In recent years, the wholesale company has been the subject of several controls and banning decisions.  Contact with Danish colleagues The delivery in question, which according to the environmental administration had come from the Netherlands, is still taped up in the premises and is to be destroyed under the supervision of the municipality - We have also been in contact with our Danish colleagues on the other side of the strait. It is about a very large volume, and overall the data we have indicates a certain systematicity, says Caroline Tandefelt to News Agency Siren. The property where the environmental administration's raid took place is owned by another company with partly the same group of owners. Several wholesale companies in the food industry have their warehouses nearby.
30a5831fe67213b9a31432f9080572301030c44f: Livia went for the bench press record - then she broke both arms
bc93af5c72c807b977b09509cb2ee6ef7d4a655c: The accident occurred during the bench press WC in Eskilstuna on January 25. After lifting 170 kilos, Livia Blomqvist, 23, tried to break the Nordic record of 178 kilos. During the lift, she heard a crack - and then another - as the bar ended up at the wrong angle and both arms broke. - Then it felt like in that second the dream of the World Cup came crashing down, says Livia Blomqvist in Nyhetsmorgon.  "The second time in my life I've heard of this" Blomqvist competed in the so-called equipped bench press, a technical branch where everything has to be right. She says that her shoulder blades gave way, causing the bar to go backwards towards her head. The arm ended up at such a bad angle that the leg came off and she lost control of the bar - then the other arm came off too.  Chief physician Mikael Sandström states that it is very unusual for athletes to break both arms at the same time. - It is the second time in my life I have heard about this, says Sandström. Despite the injury, Blomqvist managed to qualify for both the WC and EC, but now awaits a long rehabilitation.  - I try to maintain my body as much as possible and hope to be able to train lighter weights as soon as possible, she says. Tough way back Despite the setback, Blomqvist is determined to get back to the competition scene. She continues to train what she can and hopes that the injury may even give her body time to heal old wear and tear. - If only I can train 40 kilos in the bench press, it will do a lot for my strength, says Blomqvist. The doctors have prescribed at least twelve weeks of rest from heavy load, which makes the WC in May unlikely. Blomqvist is now aiming to be back at the EC in August. - You'll see how the body responds, but I've made up my mind that the EC in August is a more realistic goal.
4f4ea05aaca4380b26dbc0f7944b1021c6223287: Sharp increase in defense spray - after the murders: "A security"
9fc56a98f687bfa77dbd2363d093ca83bbc2cbf2: Amanda Blom received her first defense spray from her father when she was only 13 years old.  - It is my father who has said that it is important since I was little, so then it has just followed me into adulthood, says Amanda Blom in Nyhetsmorgon.  In her social media, she has promoted defense spray, something that has led to a positive response from women who she states bought the product after her videos. From the men, the reactions have looked different. - They were very negative about my video and commented a lot. That we imagine that we are so vulnerable. They probably wanted to ridicule it a little in some way, says Amanda Blom.  Defense spray may be carried and used in Sweden for self-defense in an emergency situation. Johanna Björkman, legal expert, explains where the line is drawn between emergency protection and assault. - You always have to defend yourself against, for example, an unprovoked or ongoing attack. But you must never be the one who initiates something by starting to use this spray, for example unnecessarily or to ward off someone who may not have an intention at all or has misunderstood something, says Johanna Björkman.  "The body thinks it's burning" Defense spray is legal, unlike pepper spray, which is illegal to possess, buy or bring into Sweden. Chemist Johanna Thompson explains what the various products contain and how they affect the body.  - In both cases, it is a hijacking of the body's own defense system, says Johanna Thompson.  Pepper spray contains the active substance capsaicin, which is extracted from chili fruit.  - The body thinks it's on fire. It is an immediate, inflammatory, very strong reaction, says Johanna Thompson.  She also says that it can cause shortness of breath and lasting pain. Unlike pepper spray, defense spray instead gives signals of extreme cold.  - Here we have a base of menthol in most cases and solvents that will help the menthol to cross the protective membrane of the eye, says Johanna Thompson.  The risks of defense sprays Defense

d6b3cd4eb20350402e7ba211fa8e09316b0b58af: Trump's new move raises anger: It could endanger millions of lives
3c704ea8cbf890893a583d8c948889285a3cf6cf: It's been in the works for a long time - but now it seems to be close.  The Trump administration plans this week to overturn a scientific decision from Barack Obama's time as president that is the basis for large parts of the United States' climate policy, The Wall Street Journal reports. If the decision is implemented, it will be the most extensive dismantling of the country's climate policy to date. It is about the so-called "endangerment finding" from 2009, where it was determined that six greenhouse gases pose a threat to human health and welfare. The decision has been the legal basis for the environmental authority EPA's climate rules, including emission limits for power plants and stricter fuel requirements for vehicles. - This is the largest deregulation in the history of the United States, says EPA director Lee Zeldin. Trump has called climate change a hoax Trump already tried during his first term to weaken or dismantle parts of the US's climate regulations. The American president has previously called climate change "the biggest hoax" ever invented by man. - The carbon footprint is a hoax invented by people with evil intentions, and it points the way to total destruction, he said in a speech to the UN General Assembly last year. The new decision, which is expected to be announced later this week, removes requirements for measuring, reporting, certifying and complying with federal emission standards for motor vehicles. Also associated control programs, credit systems and reporting requirements for the industry are to be abolished, according to the administration. However, the change does not apply to rules for emissions from power plants and other stationary sources, such as oil and gas facilities. But overturning the original decision could pave the way for those rules to be dismantled as well, writes The Wall Street Journal. The criticism: Could endanger millions of lives The fossil fuel industry is expected to be the big winner - which has long opposed federal climate regulations. 2822678943a3fcdd68a956e00eaa1fea3a6c254b: That's how corrupt Sweden is: "We are the second worst in the Nordics"
173288092b46e285a5565767357d31440dd26a16:
Transparency International's index measures how corrupt a country's public sector is perceived by experts and business. The countries receive a score between 0 and 100 – where higher scores mean less corruption.

This year, Denmark, Finland and Singapore top the list, while South Sudan, Somalia and Venezuela end up at the bottom. Sweden gets 80 points, which is a clear drop from 89 ten years ago. Three areas stand out According to Transparency International Sweden, there are three areas that particularly affect Sweden's results. Organized crime with infiltration and illicit influence poses a serious threat to welfare systems. - It is about organized crime with infiltration, unauthorized influence, extortion and the like. Where companies are used as criminal tools, for example, says Ulrik Åshuvud.

In addition, Sweden lags behind in transparency and control in public procurement, where several cases of pure corruption have been noticed. - There is a lot of money in procurement. These are large public resources. Over a trillion, i.e. a thousand billion, is procured for in public Sweden today, says Ulrik Åshuvud.

Finally, conflicts of interest are raised, where the ability to refrain from participating in decisions is questioned. - The third thing that we usually talk about is conflicts of interest, that is, the ability to take a step back and realize that maybe you shouldn't be part of the decision-making process or that you shouldn't influence certain decisions, says Ulrik Åshuvud. Political integrity questioned Before the 2022 election, Kalla revealed the facts that five out of eight parties in the Riksdag were prepared to receive secret contributions to the election campaign, which may have affected Sweden's position. - That made us change our direction quite a lot. We didn't have any priority regarding political integrity, we probably thought it worked quite well. We can't say that it did then and maybe it still doesn't, says Ulrik Åshuvud. Several legislative proposals underway Today there are proposals and legislative amendments on boron

49bd4ea9cd7a7f7d4ece32cd8cc526d7acdfb788: The lawyer's threat - send criminal clients on the ex-girlfriend
331ce8623c35794615f62ad269851c0735a2e1d6: During the summer and autumn of last year, a lawyer in Dalarna allegedly committed several serious crimes against his former girlfriend. According to the indictment, the man, who is in his 40s, secretly filmed, threatened with a knife and abused her. And when the lawyer understood that she was about to report him, he allegedly used his position to intimidate her into silence. According to the indictment, he threatened the girlfriend to send a former client on her. The woman testifies that he says his clients will do "anything" for him, gave her the name of a convicted felon and threatened to have a "quick talk" with her. Recorded the conversation The lawyer also threatened to counter-report the woman for rape if she went ahead with a police report, something she recorded with the phone: "You say you're going to report me for rape," she says in the recording. "Yes, I will have to," he replies. When asked why he needs it, he replies that he has to "protect himself". "Okay, so you protect yourself. There's no reason to report anyone, is it? Unless I've done it." "That's how it works." The woman tells in questioning that she feels afraid of him and gets heart palpitations when she hears his voice after the events. Denies crime The lawyer is now charged with gross breach of the peace, which includes the violent crimes, and assault in court proceedings. He denies any crime, and believes that the bruises she says occurred during an assault are due to her "stumbling into things". Last fall, the man received a warning and a fine of SEK 250,000 from the Bar Association after appearing under the influence in the district court, according to Falu-Kuriren. In addition, he was convicted of aggravated drunken driving twice in one year.

b0ede7355d756568ca76512e2b50af7d358a1de5: The Western alliance is being tested in Munich - will be a thriller
220e61e38fe7f09e99d4df20b066ab13f0f3456b: Outside the luxury hotel Bayerischer Hof in central Munich, there are small lit candles, flowers and dozens of pictures of the "king of pop" - Michael Jackson. It was when he died that a statue in a park outside the hotel became a pilgrimage site for grieving fans.  In a bizarre dispute over the years, two rival gangs of Jackson lovers emerged who claimed the makeshift monument as theirs. They tore down each other's tributes in nocturnal raids. But for the next few days, the Jackson gang will be allowed to continue their rivalry out of sight. The monument is located within the security zone for the annual security conference in Munich. Kristersson and three ministers on site Prime Minister Kristersson is coming from Sweden with three ministers. German Chancellor Friedrich Merz is there, of course, along with around 60 other leaders, such as Ukraine's Zelensky. That J.D. Vance not attending has raised many questions. Does that mean the Trump administration has decided to lower the temperature?  Extending a "We Are the World"-like olive branch to European leaders? Or will Secretary of State Marco Rubio give an equally confrontational speech? The so-called peace plan for Ukraine will be discussed. The so-called cease-fire in Gaza will be dissected. The so-called arrest of Venezuela's Maduro will be criticized, at least somewhat quietly, and the so-called negotiations on the future of Greenland will be high on the agenda. A circus even outside the hotel Outside the congress, we can expect a Jackson-like circus. Hundreds of thousands of exiled Iranians are expected to demonstrate Saturday against the country's rule, and the son of Iran's last shah will speak. c960f494c376d2facd2597f5e17cbffaedfeaa9d: The expert on the verdict: End of the "wild west" for influencers
045ac143c3e53bc74b0860b60c52ede1fc185d81: Youtuber Pontus Rasmusson had unreported income of almost 2.3 million in 2020 and 2021. On Thursday, he was sentenced to prison for serious accounting offenses against his denial, which TV4 Nyheterna reported on. Emanuel Karlsten, journalist and chairman of the Media Academy, believes that the verdict can have several positive effects. - This may put an end to the circus that has been. By the "circus" he refers to the influencer market on platforms such as YouTube and Tiktok, where content creators have made a lot of money on, what it seemed, completely their own terms. "The Internet is not a total free zone" Karlsten believes that this sentence, together with the sentence against Christofer "Crippa" Lundström, can help set the boundaries in the YouTube world. - These are two examples of how the internet is not a total free zone, but an arena where influencers must play by the same rules as everyone else. He believes that the judges will become warning examples for future content creators. - There will surely be more judgments of this type. The influencer market has been the wild west for a long time. It may be easy to believe that you live in a parallel universe with an audience of millions, but you live in the real world. - Now there will be a reference. In both Pontus and Chrippa's case, it has been a matter of a lack of basic accounting skills. It will be easier to refer to these two judgments in the future. "Not a world for him" Furthermore, Emanuel Karlsten believes that the verdict is positive for Pontus Rasmusson personally. - It is obvious that this is not a world for him. 146920e1dfd9b480a7c1f6469f53f2049292be09: Over the past decade, the number of colon cancer cases has increased, especially in the 50-59 age group. The EU now recommends that member states offer screening from the age of 50, but in Sweden the starting age is still 60. The National Board of Health and Welfare justifies its decision by saying that there is a lack of sufficient scientific evidence that screening between the ages of 50 and 59 would reduce mortality, and that there is a lack of staff and the risk of unequal care. - We don't understand how the National Board of Health and Welfare has thought here, says Birger Pålsson, docent and chief physician. He participated in the National Board of Health and Welfare's expert group that recommended starting screening at the age of 50. He estimates that between 50 and 100 people in the age group 50–59 per year could be saved if screening were introduced earlier. - What we have criticized very harshly is that there is a large amount of international scientific reports that unanimously show this. The National Board of Health and Welfare has not reviewed the modern scientific literature. We were only tasked with reviewing four articles and they are a little old at this point. But paradoxically, most of them also recommend starting at age 50, says Pålsson. Spotted a lump Lotta Hammar was diagnosed at the age of 53, by which time the cancer had already spread. She says that the symptoms were unclear and that she first suspected menopause. - I thought: I'm tired, it's menopause. I'm getting rounder, it's menopause. I blamed it all on: It must be the menopause. It wasn't in my world that it would be something, she says in Efter fem. It wasn't until she discovered a lump the size of a tennis ball sticking out of the left side of her stomach that she checked it out. By then she had been suffering from fatigue and other symptoms for a year. - It had gone so far that I had colon cancer that had spread metastases. So it had gone way too far. When she got the cancer news, she didn't believe it at first. The hardest part of all was telling her children. - They

bd980c2e964450216282c32c4d8b99c5acaaf944: See the incredible pictures - a mile out on the ice: "Fantastic natural phenomenon"
57595c2cba7e4baf3f456ad8643dc87f45a63b55: The ice has been thick on Kvarken along the Finnish coast for a long time. So thick that Ylva von Wright and a friend took on a challenge: to get as close to Sweden as possible on cross-country skates. - We guessed that we would come across a chute with open water, but we wanted to see how far we could go, says Ylva von Wright to TV4 Nyheterna. Ylva and the friend, who are studying to become wilderness guides, had time to get about eight kilometers out on the water before they started to encounter ice banks. The first embankment was still, but a couple of hundred meters out they heard the sound of embankments moving. - We got to experience a fantastic natural phenomenon. What I like about the ice that makes it so fascinating is that you can never plan anything ahead of time because the conditions can change so quickly. "Risk of being separated from land" According to SMHI, ice dams can form when the ice is pressed against land or other larger blocks of ice. For this, however, it is required that the ice is thicker than 15-20 centimeters.  The flakes that form the dykes are not usually frozen together, and Ylva and her friend became aware of this when the ice began to crack a little further out. Even the innermost dike began to move over time. - There was a risk that we would end up on an ice floe and be separated from the coast, so it was best to turn around. You must be aware of the risks and respect nature when you go out on the ice. However, they never felt any direct concern. - Since we were in the archipelago, we were quite close to islands, so it didn't feel like we were that far out, says Ylva von Wright. Had food for two days Since the plan was to get as close to the Swedish coast as possible, Ylva von Wright and her friend had really tickled themselves. In addition to the usual equipment of ice spikes, throwing line and dry clothes packed in waterproof sacks, they carried food for two days and four liters of water each. Did you think you would reach Sweden? - No, it was more of a fun idea. You would have needed a packraft to get over the chute. At certain times of the day you can cross the gutter

552165a644c8ff76662b42135d039cf6de495d16: That's why the cold bites - despite global warming
bb609c44a066babb45dfbd394fefa5ac5bbb120f: In large parts of northern Europe and North America, January this year has been colder than normal. In Sweden, temperature deficits were noted throughout the country, especially in the northern parts, where in places it was down to eight degrees colder than normal.  - You must also distinguish between weather and climate. We have cold weather right now. But the climate is warmer and is warming up, says meteorologist Peter Kondrup. Jet streams are affected by climate change At the same time as the cold has taken hold in Sweden, South America and Australia have been affected by heat waves and fires. Peter Kondrup explains that the jet streams, which normally move across the Northern Hemisphere, have become slower and more elongated because the polar regions are warming faster than the equator. This leads to larger and slower oscillations, which can produce both colder and warmer periods than normal.  - There can be very large but slow, tough swings. It is an effect of climate change, of global warming. "We have a bad memory" The past twelve years have been the warmest globally, and 2025 was the third warmest year to date. Although this year's January is perceived as cold, it is a mild winter in a longer historical perspective.  - We experience January 2026 as very cold, but compare it to the war winters of the 1940s, then it appears as a pale copy. It was really cold then. Or in the 80s.  For the past 20 years, we have experienced unusually mild winters in Sweden, which may have made us forget how cold it can actually be in winter. - We feel that it is cold and it is a little colder than it has been in a few years. Our memory is quite short. We've gotten used to this global warming, and when it gets a little colder than normal, we think it's freezing cold, says Peter Kondrup.
7f4e252829944e0e61177741aca20fb7f3086004: Took food waste home and got fired - now Marie gets compensation
0207c894c5bc556ce7f9407176db2c57a00e83d7: Marie Hansson had worked as a cook in a special accommodation for 17 years when she was suddenly called to a meeting with the manager. There she was accused of theft because she had brought food waste home - and was fired.  - I was completely speechless and thought it was a joke. It came out of nowhere, I hadn't even been told.  Marie enjoyed her work very well and describes it as a shock when the news came - two days before her 50th birthday.  - I decided then and there that it wasn't right. You shouldn't behave that way. Sued the employer Marie sued her employer Skurup Municipality a year and a half ago. Her representative Bo Villner believes that the employer's action was disproportionate and believes that there were other solutions to the situation.  - Our opinion is that it is a trivial incident. There's no reason to believe she wouldn't have stopped if only she had been asked. Why an employer chooses to do so is difficult to know, he believes.  - It can be due to several things. You can have prestige behind it or you dislike someone and want to get rid of them. But this is a bit like cracking nuts with a sledgehammer.  To Sydsvenskan, Egil Ceylan, head of office at Skurup's municipality, informs that he cannot comment on the individual case.  "Standing up for myself" Marie Hansson has received a lot of support after the incident.  - Both from acquaintances and strangers, everyone says it was well done and gives me a pat on the back. To this day, Marie has not received any explanation as to why she was not given a warning or notice. - If they had told me to stop it, of course I would have done it. Now she hopes her case can help others in similar situations. - I stand up for myself and maybe this can support someone else too. You have to have the courage to speak up when things don't go right.
853a5b21f2f0dbdacb1472c53a358699b270f36c: Here the record rocket takes off
36354369ff27810dda3b4eaa0f467812a81cea33: The launch took place from Europe's space base in French Guiana at 17:45 Swedish time. It is the sixth flight of Ariane 6, but the first with four boosters – a configuration known as Ariane 64. The rocket can now lift about 21.6 tonnes into low orbit, more than double that of previous versions.  The goal of today's launch is to place 32 satellites into orbit, as part of Amazon's rollout of a satellite-based internet system.  European competitiveness in space Ariane 6 is developed to give Europe independent and competitive access to space, the Swedish Space Agency writes on its blog. The version has a longer nose cone than before and is the largest Ariane 6 to date. The rocket is 62 meters, equivalent to a high-rise building with 20 floors. The increased capacity means that larger and heavier loads can be launched at the same time, which is crucial when the number of satellites in orbit is rapidly increasing. Clear Swedish contributions Sweden contributes to the Ariane 6 program via the European Space Agency ESA.  The company GKN Aerospace in Trollhättan develops and manufactures, among other things, nozzles and turbines for the rocket's engines.  "The launch marks an important step for Europe's space transport and shows how European cooperation, with contributions from several countries, strengthens Europe's ability to reach and use space," writes the Swedish Space Agency.

My, 25, disappeared the night before Boxing Day and was found murdered the following day. On Thursday afternoon, she was buried in the Oscar church in Stockholm. My's family decided to make the funeral open to the public because the murder received so much attention. Rönning resident Patrik Fransson has made it to Stockholm to attend. - I feel that I want to be here to show respect for the family, he says. He hopes that the funeral will be an opportunity for people to come together. - I see quite a lot of hatred and strong emotions. I think it is good that people can come into contact with each other and share feelings together and unite in love, he says. "Hope they can move on" Delmon Haffo, a moderate municipal politician in Salem, is also present, but more as a concerned Rönningebo than as a politician, he says.

- For me, it is very important to show support to the family and everyone involved and to show that society is behind them, he says. He didn't know My personally, but knew who she was. They had several mutual friends. - I am above all here because I was touched by something incredible that this could happen in Rönninge, he says. - I hope it will be a nice end to the family's grief work. I hope that they get the opportunity to move on and that we get a church filled with love. The family's statement: "The loss is bottomless" My's family does not want to talk to the press in connection with the funeral, but yesterday they shared this statement: We want to thank everyone who has shown us warmth, care and support. It means a lot to us. Our beloved daughter, My, loved sunsets, seas and open horizons. She was curious and brave and stood firm in her convictions, with an obvious respect for others. My spoke more about the world than about herself and never gave up on what she believed in. My was quick-thinking and full of life, with a special ability to capture moments – in pictures, on film and in meetings with people. She saw the vividness in every situation and spread joy about SEK

f187772d32cdd2374b098ad5b053fdc327998079: The judgment concerns deficiencies in the accounting during the years 2020 and 2021. Pontus Rasmusson then had unreported income of almost SEK 2.3 million.  The investigation has shown that he kept the accounts on paper instead of using an accounting program. During the trial, he has emphasized that he was young and inexperienced. He has also said that during that period he had to endure a lot of hate and threats and that he then prioritized YouTube over his accounting. But the court states that he was aware that he was running a business subject to bookkeeping and that he was completely indifferent to whether the bookkeeping met the requirements.  Commenting himself Pontus Rasmusson denies any crime. On Snapchat, he writes that the district court chose not to see all the evidence. He also writes that he has read the majority of similar judges where "the outcome has been completely different" "An unpunished person should not be assessed with the harshest punishment on the punishment scale" he also writes and thinks that he has now "learned". The channel was shut down He was also charged with complicating tax control. The court considers that it is a crime that should be included in one of the accounting crimes.  27-year-old Rasmusson was previously one of Sweden's biggest YouTubers aimed at children, but in 2022 his channel was shut down. According to Google, he had violated the child safety policy, which prohibits content that sexualizes minors. In addition to two cases of serious accounting offences, he is convicted of complicating tax control. He is also sentenced to pay SEK 50,000 in corporate fines.

8d72bb5504217611de64c8258f9de32338f274f9: Annelie was found dead in the lake - Juha Marttila, 56, is convicted of murder
f74448fef678de19eee61e1503c0de124ed5eb42: The family understood that something was wrong when 46-year-old Annelie Nevborn Eriksson had not heard from her children after she disappeared from her home on December 6, 2024. The next day, her brother Andreas Törnkvist reported her missing. A large search effort was launched, Missing People was called in and over 200 people volunteered to participate in the search. Three months after she disappeared, she was found dead in a lake, wrapped in a blanket in a garbage bag - at the same time her 56-year-old Juha Marttila was arrested. Today he was sentenced to 18 years in prison for murder and violation of grave peace. - The district court has, after an examination of a series of circumstantial evidence, concluded that it is beyond reasonable doubt that the man killed the woman and then moved the body in the way that the prosecutor has claimed. Other perpetrators can be excluded, says court president Anne Olsson.  Got an early tip about the roommate In the investigation, it appears that the police had been keeping an eye on Juha Marttila for some time. Relatives had stated that they got a strange feeling when they talked to him. Missing People also alerted the police to Juha Marttila. After searching for a week, they advised the police that they wanted to do an internal search. Then he had contacted an acquaintance to move furniture in the home. The partner must also have stated that they had recently broken up. "Missing People got bad vibes from this. First, that they had broken up just before the disappearance, but also that he was so careful to move under furniture right after Missing People's phone call," writes the police who received the tip.  Had similar garbage bags at home The same kind of garbage bags that she was found in were also found in Juha Marttila's residence. The fibers that were in the blanket were also found in his car and on thresholds in the home.  The prosecutor said that they had extensive technical evidence and that several interrogations pointed to Juha Marttila as having committed the murder. 1e8c2ed92ee218dbdb36b8ce7de3aa4a7dee784b: US used mysterious superweapon against cartel drones
3f87b8223939f9084afbe6bae1e3e5d835003e2a: On Wednesday, the US aviation authority FAA closed the airspace over the city of El Paso on the border with Mexico in southern Texas in the US.  The shutdown, which lasted a total of seven hours, meant, among other things, that no planes could take off from the international airport in the city. The reason behind the shutdown is that drones belonging to Mexican drug cartels have crossed the border, says US Transport Minister Sean Duffy on X. Used super weapon The US responded by resorting to a weapon they had never used before, reports the Reuters news agency. According to sources with insight, it is a kind of anti-drone weapon with direct energy technology - i.e. the same type of technology that the US is suspected of having used in connection with the strike against Venezuela's now deposed President Nicolás Maduro. Neither the Pentagon nor AeroVironment, the company behind the drone, have commented on the data. When the information about the drone came from Mexico, the FAA initially said that the airport in El Paso would remain closed for up to ten days.  Delayed Valentine's Day trip Two people affected by the stop were Jorge Rueda and Yamilexi Meza who were scheduled to fly to Portland, Oregon for a Valentine's Day trip. - I am happy that ten days became only two hours for us, Jorge Rueda told AP after their flight was rebooked. According to documents from the Pentagon, over a thousand drone observations are made a month on the border with Mexico. According to Reuters, the authorities are working on dealing with these, especially around airports and large events.

e8d5084360bea447a7f4ceaea1293dac3e2dd302: Finland vaccinates Russian rabies foxes: "Don't touch"
28d727c8b92e9ac0fbfd1ddacf2a7fc1cef2713f: Foul-smelling packages have been placed along Finland's eastern border to stop rabies from entering the country. The packages contain fish-scented baits with vaccines, specially formulated for wild predators such as foxes and raccoons. The background is reports of rabies cases in the Moscow region of Russia. Despite that, the situation is calm, according to the experts. - Bait vaccines have been distributed every year since the early 1990s. It is a proven and effective method to prevent the spread of rabies, says Tiina Nokireki, senior researcher at the Swedish Food Agency, to the Finnish Ilta Sanomat.  Rabies-free for 30 years Finland has been classified as rabies-free for around 30 years. The vaccines are being distributed across the southeastern border, which is considered the most likely route for the infection to enter from Russia. Last fall, around 180,000 vaccine doses were released in the area. But despite the outbreak in Moscow, the risk has not increased, emphasizes Nokireki. - Vaccines have also been distributed on the Russian side, and besides, the distance is long. Animals don't move such long distances, she tells the newspaper. Do not touch the baits - vaccinate your pets The vaccine baits smell really bad and should be left alone. If humans touch them, animals may avoid them due to human weathering. It is also not advisable to come into contact with the vaccine solution inside the bait. At the same time, the authorities remind us of the importance of vaccinating pets. - Dogs and cats should be vaccinated against rabies throughout the country, says Nokireki. Should rabies still reach Finland, it is more likely that the infection will first spread to pets and then on to humans - rather than humans being infected directly by wild animals, according to the Finnish Food Agency.

a4c20fe39f17d6ffe2e7af3e05964720aba26d19: Over a million exiled Iranians demonstrated
37312e8b780af95ae9eaa7df77a8977660c99858:
On Saturday, more than a million exiled Iranians rallied in cities around the world in support of the Iranian people after the ousted Shah's son Reza Pahlavi called for a "global day of action" with a particular focus on Munich, Toronto and Los Angeles. In Munich, where the annual security conference was taking place in parallel, German police said around 250,000 people took part in the demonstration. Reza Pahlavi himself attended the security conference and spoke, among other things, with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. 

Pahlavi also attended the demonstration where he gave a speech. - We tell all grieving families that they are not alone. As a child, father, husband and brother, I understand the pain of the grieving families. Not a day has passed without me shedding tears, but these tears give me energy, he told the large crowd at the venue. US Senator Lindsey Graham also spoke at the demonstration and expressed support for the Iranian people's struggle for democracy. 

- Help is on the way, he said during his speech. An estimated 350,000 people gathered in Toronto and about the same number attended in Los Angeles. In Britain, police reported that 50,000 people took part in the demonstrations. The participants chanted slogans against the Iranian regime and expressed support for the relatives of the thousands of people killed during the protests in Iran more than a month ago.

Thousands also gathered in Stockholm and Gothenburg to demonstrate against the Iranian regime.

725091793bc9e17d0a6bae96d8b7eadfc824c672: Hope for babies: New weapon against RS virus
ce6a0996875e9eb6645862e487fbf690d8be574c: Every season, an average of 1,650 children over the course of a year need hospital care due to RS virus infection. In a country with good healthcare, it is not a fatal disease, but worried parents come to the children's emergency room with babies who have difficulty breathing when the cough, fever and phlegm hit. Small children's airways are more seriously affected by the RS virus, so they may need breathing support in the form of oxygen. When small children get sick with a high fever, they may find it difficult to eat, and then they get a tube down their stomach with nutrition, says Susanne Strömdahl, infectious disease doctor and investigator at the Norwegian Public Health Agency. The very youngest children, who are only a few months old, can sometimes suffer from breathing pauses, so-called apneas. Hope for a turning point Now there is hope for a turning point, which could lead to a significantly reduced burden on children's healthcare during the winter months - and reduced suffering for the very smallest. Since September 10 last year, newborns are offered an injection with antibodies against the RS virus. A majority of parents have agreed. It is not surprising, but it is very gratifying that the majority choose to accept with the big win for the smallest children to be protected for the first winter season. Is it revolutionary? Yes, it is based on the international data we see reported, says Susanne Strömdahl. Not one hundred percent. She describes the medicine as safe. So far, there have been five reports of side effects in Sweden, and in those cases it has mainly been a fine dotted rash or redness and swelling at the injection site. The antibodies provide good, but not 100% protection against serious illness. After the treatment began to be offered, the Public Health Agency has only received reports of a few children who received antibodies and still suffered RS virus infection. We expect a large protective effect. But in this situation, we are just at the beginning of the spread of infection. We had the start of the season in week five. The advice to protect babies from meeting cold people outside is approached

When the calendar has now moved to February, the New Year's Eve fireworks have died down, but the debate about whether or not fireworks should be used continues. Are they a natural part of the festive season or do they just cause unnecessary suffering to animals and people? On February 17, the defense committee will consider several received motions concerning bans or restrictions on fireworks. Before that, 13 organizations have come together and written an open letter urging the committee to take the motions seriously and consider a total ban on fireworks for private individuals.  Can suffer lifelong hearing damage The letter has been signed by several animal welfare organizations, but also by blue light personnel, including the Swedish Police Association.

- Today, we mainly have hearing damage that is sometimes lifelong and that you can't do anything about. We don't have, pepper pepper, no cops that have had any of these pyrotechnics in the face or anything like that. But on the day it happens, considering how potent these fireworks are, we run the risk of even worse injuries or death, says Björn Johnsson, regional head security representative of the Swedish Police Association. In a survey among the members of the Police Association, 13 percent of police officers on external duty answered that they had been fired upon with fireworks. The industry does not believe that bans solve problems The industry does not believe that a ban would have solved this type of problem. 

- It would have reduced some ordinary fireworks and not least it would have reduced for those who are law abiding and already behave themselves. On the other hand, the rather large part of illegal fireworks imports had certainly increased. It's already big and it wouldn't disappear, unfortunately, says Martin Hildeberg, treasurer of Sweden's Pyrotechnic Industry Association.

But Björn Johnsson of the Swedish Police Association does not agree that a ban would mainly affect the law-abiding.

7fb2a5a4ce2abc2fdff2a22d38417a80d2e378eb: CIA manual from World War II goes viral in the US
c37de03fc58e55c3246925a74de56a370dddb21a: The text was written during World War II by William "Wild Bill" Donovan, head of the Office of Strategic Services which later became the CIA. The manual was published in 2008. In the last month, it has been downloaded nearly 60,000 times and is now the fifth most popular e-book on Project Gutenberg, an American literature project that works to make available literature that is not covered by copyright. Small actions slow down the system The manual describes so-called "simple sabotage". It is about everyday behaviors that, if repeated, can make it difficult for a bureaucracy to function. Among the advice is to: Give long speeches and drag out meetings.  Bring up side issues and discuss details unnecessarily.  "Misunderstanding" instructions, asking many questions and delaying answers. It is also suggested to play dumb, be as annoying and argumentative as possible without breaking rules, as well as to stop talking when representatives of the regime enter a room. The purpose, according to the authors, is to make the work of the police and security services more difficult, but also to give ordinary people a way to show resistance to decisions they perceive as unacceptable. Attention in today's USA Why the manual has gone viral right now is unclear. According to the online newspaper 404 Media, the interest coincides with a period of unrest and change in the American workplace, especially among government employees. Questions of loyalty, reorganizations and new demands on employees have become more common in a more polarized political climate. During Donald Trump's time in power, discussions about the role of the state and the independence of the authorities have again taken place in the public debate. In that context, the old CIA manual has received new attention among some readers. On a large online forum for government employees, one of the most-read posts is headlined: "To my colleagues, especially veterans: we are at war." There, the manual is shared primarily as a historical document – ​​and as a basis for discussion.

6abcea26b8355b6e03098722cdd7122f02d5c26e: Saga Ludvigsson and Medina straight to the final in Mello
c5a87b5e936c858c536627b471430ae803a9e2c4: Saga Ludvigsson makes it to the final with the country pop song "Ain't today". The 20-year-old from Örby in Västergötland promised more energy after Friday's rehearsal and now it is clear that her contribution has gone home with the viewers. She debuted with the contribution "Hate you so much" last year, won her preliminary competition and finished in twelfth and last place in the final. This year, Ludvigsson describes his contribution as a little more cocky, more mature and darker. Favorite love song Hip-hop duo Medina predicted their chances as good with the contribution "Viva l'amor" on Valentine's Day. It also went down well with the audience, the contribution received the most votes. Made up of veterans Sami Rekik and Ali Jammali, Medina were favorites from the start. The duo has previously come in third and second place in the Melodifestivalen and has stated during the week that it would be like a "fairy tale" if they win the entire competition this year. As recently as January, Sami Rekik took a timeout due to physical and mental exhaustion. However, it is not something that has been noticed during the rehearsals this week. With a massive confetti rain of red hearts, a torchlight parade and dancers with maximum energy, Medina has lived up to expectations. The youngest participant in the qualifiers, Eva Jumatate, took third place and thus goes to the finals with the entry "Selfish". She is the youngest participant in Melodifestivalen 2026 and has previously said that it feels nerve-wracking to make her debut, but that the fact that she is participating in her hometown of Kristianstad has calmed her nerves. When Jumatate participated in Talent as a ten-year-old, she moved Bianca Ingrosso to tears. Eight years later, she once again performs a ballad that has proven to be a hit on TV sofas. The difference is that she wrote the song herself and participates as an artist under her own name.

Wanted to create something new Elina Kouthoofd, who is the project manager at Skansen, says that the idea of ​​a winter wedding was sparked by the desire to create something new based on the popular summer concept.  - We run drop-in weddings in the summer and have done so for ten years. So we saw before 2026 that Valentine's Day was on a Saturday. Then we thought: Shouldn't we test the drop-in concept, but in the winter? Then there was a winter wedding on February 14, she says.  The atmosphere during Valentine's Day at Skansen is described as magical and filled with love.  - So much love in the air and in every place. It's magical, says Elina Kouthoofd.  In Seglora church from the 18th century, Tina Aandalen and Karl Aspengren got married. With around fifty guests, a priest and lively music, the couple exchanged rings in the historic building. However, the courtship took place just under two months ago.  - Karl proposed on the morning of Christmas Eve. We felt: Now we're driving! Yet we have waited over ten years for it to happen. Then it was just as good to just have it felled, says Tina Aandalen.  Groom Karl Aspengren wants to encourage others to take the plunge.  - If you feel like getting married, get married. Malmer Stenergard points out that the more conciliatory tone from the US will not necessarily last over time. - Rubio extended a hand and said that you want to cooperate with Europe, you want things to go well for Europe. But the collaboration must take place where it is good for us. - In the conversations I have had with him, it has always been very constructive. However, other representatives have sounded different. We all remember the speech in Munich last year and Trump's statements about Greenland Focus on "white Europe" Dag Blanck, senior professor of North American studies at Uppsala University, believes that Rubio's speech is strongly influenced by American domestic politics. - This is a speech that speaks to Trump's core voters to a great extent, says Blanck.  He points out that minority groups such as African Americans, Latinos, Asians and indigenous peoples are completely excluded in Rubio's picture of Europe. According to Blanck, Rubio's message was a clear nationalist vision: - He criticized immigration and advocated a Europe that strengthens itself rather than driving global cooperation. He mentioned his roots in Spain and Italy, but not Cuba, and barely spoke at all about democracy or human rights. The focus was instead on Western European culture as a basis for cooperation, says Blanck. - You can say that it is a very narrow view of Europe, where it is defined as "white Europe", and where other groups are excluded from the picture. There is a clear connection to domestic politics in the United States.  Independence in focus European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen called Rubio's speech "very reassuring", but pointed out that other representatives in the administration have a tougher tone. - Europe has no other choice but to become independent. We are facing a very strong threat from external forces that are trying to weaken our union from within, says von der Leyen.  At the same time, she also emphasized the need for increased defense

017d042088202bbbd62c33c8e5bc4b020b011cb0: Because the family lives less than two kilometers from the bus stop, their six-year-old son Hjalmar is denied a school bus by the municipality of Storuman. He therefore has to walk along the E12 – where the cars drive at 90 kilometers per hour.  - It's scary. When trucks come, I feel like I'm going to be run over, he says.  The parents Johanna and Krister have appealed the decision to the administrative court, which assesses the stretch as dangerous for traffic. Even so, Hjalmar is not entitled to a taxi because they live too close to the pick-up point.  - We want the children to be treated fairly and here their safety is not taken into account, says Hjalmar's mother Johanna Sundin.  Getting help from a private actor Previously, they went into the forest to avoid the road, but now a private actor has offered to pick up Hjalmar for free. The family has been told by the municipality that the school bus would cost SEK 250,000 a year, but they consider that to be irrelevant to the discussion.  - I, who work in healthcare, know that you don't say "now it costs 300,000 for us to replace your hip", says Johanna Sundin. The parents have lived in Forsmark for 17 years. The municipality is now working to attract more people to the area, but the family believes that it is difficult to motivate other families with children to move there. - You don't want to say: "come and live here in Forsmark, but your child will have to follow a European path", says Hjalmar's father Krister Näslund. Parental responsibility applies to the Chairman of the Municipal Board in Storuman municipality, Ulrik Dahlgren (S), says that the decision rests with civil servants and administrative law. He is familiar with the route and admits that there are risks with the proximity to the road.   - This is a road that we all drive many times, so you know the route itself. He explains that parental responsibility applies, which means that it is up to the parents to follow Hjalmar to the bus stop. df407f76948d1766e7f3ed02cb597802f07f3c24: Navalny died on February 16, 2024 in a penal colony in Siberia. Russian authorities have claimed he died of natural causes, but the Russian version is contested. Now a new investigation shows that he was poisoned with epibatidine – an extremely potent poison extracted from the skin of South American poison dart frogs and many times stronger than morphine. The symptoms include paralysis, severe convulsions and respiratory arrest and greatly increased blood pressure. - We have confirmed that a deadly toxin was found in Alexei Navalny's body. "Only the Russian government had the opportunity, motive and opportunity to use it against him in prison," said British Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper. Great Britain: Russia despises its citizens The report is presented at a joint press meeting with all five countries' foreign ministers, but also Navalny's widow, during the security conference in Munich.  - That is why we are here today, to shine a spotlight on the Kremlin's barbaric attempts to silence Alexei Navalny. To show that the Russian government shows contempt for its citizens and is prepared to use this deadly poison, says Cooper. According to Sweden's Foreign Minister Maria Malmer Stenergard, experts from the five countries have been able to establish that Navalny was poisoned in Russian captivity. - With the help of experts from all five countries, we have established that he was poisoned by epibatidine. Only Russia could administer the poison because he was in captivity. Most likely, it was the FSB that was behind it, she says. Navalny's widow: No longer just words The investigation will now be handed over to the OPCW, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, to increase pressure on Russia. - We will hold Russia accountable in the OPCW and spread knowledge about the use of this highly potent poison to prevent its use again, says Malmer Stenergard. During the press conference, Navalny's widow, Yulia Navalny, took the opportunity to thank the European governments: - Now it's not just

8fac8b815c6deaf44a3a68e3f41b7297e9c68ce7: The answer when Europe shakes: A common Nordic defence
81f8b7180524c423aa529b26750e13d8b44c8c7a: On Friday, the security conference began in Munich, with several world leaders in attendance. Ahead of this year's conference, the organizers have chosen to highlight the "elephant in the room", namely how the US's role in the world is changing and how well-established collaborations are threatened. Last year, US Vice President JD Vance shocked when he gave his speech with a harsh tone towards Europe. This year, the tone was considerably more accommodating. During Saturday's speech, US Secretary of State Marco Rubio emphasized that Europe and the US belong together and highlighted the importance of common security. But the new security situation has caused the Nordic countries to act. - One way to strengthen our security is to merge military units on the northern flank, says Magnus Christiansson, senior lecturer in military science at the University of Defense. - The idea is to send a signal to Russia: you cannot divide us. If a war breaks out on the northern flank, we are already united from the start. Getting more intense – because of the USA Christiansson explains that the Nordic countries are thinking about what other complements they can have to their NATO membership and how they can use it to strengthen their security regionally. This as a result of the US's changed policy and with the threats against Denmark - It is a process that has existed before but is now entering a more intensive stage, he says. The Nordic defense cooperation is today based on the Nordic Defense Cooperation, Nordefco, which means various cooperations that have existed with roots going back to the Cold War. In 2024, the Nordic countries signed an agreement on a joint defense concept – something that can now be intensified. Different experiences One challenge is the different historical experiences of the Nordic countries. - What is a lie in Copenhagen is the truth in Helsinki and that poses a problem. If Russia were to make a push, it would be viewed in completely different ways in the Nordic countries, says Christiansson. - But at the same time, I think this is being done to deter Russia and that is probably one of them
b7216cc9e45dbb05319784987ae40d9548b8a044: Ulla's important message during the trill: "Doesn't have to be perfect"
96cee76a7a7275f4a0b58f0cd2b25aea3f3fb2b1: Pensioner Ulla, 69, from Nissafors, wanted to take the opportunity to highlight her home village when she sat in Nyhetsmorgon and scratched Triss.  - I come from Nissafors, a small village that is one mile from Lake Gnosjön. The joy after the scratch When Ulla scraped together a profit of SEK 15,000 a month for twenty years, there was a real howl of joy in the window. It's almost like I'm fainting, she says and takes the opportunity to send a greeting of love to her partner: - I'll be home soon.
92877eaa5b99899f21fbe64a3ae628fd080604d6: Bus loads of Iranian exiles on their way to Munich: "We will show"
baf2b6c7914ed33531662e386e4f2c562ddbb4a2: It has been more than a month since nationwide protests in Iran were crushed with brutal violence, leaving thousands dead.  At the same time, the annual security conference is taking place in Munich, where the exiled Crown Prince Reza Pahlavi is calling for global demonstrations against the regime on Saturday, focusing on the big cities of Munich, Los Angeles and Toronto. "Iranians abroad and freedom-loving people around the world, February 14 is the global day of action in solidarity with Iran's Sun and Lion Revolution, a day to take to the streets and force the international community to take urgent, practical measures in support of the Iranian people," he wrote in a post on X. Exile Iranians from around the world, including Sweden, are now joining the demonstration. Several buses have departed from Gothenburg, Malmö and Stockholm to the giant demonstration that is expected in Munich.  Want to show unity On board one of the buses from Malmö is the Swedish-Iranian Fariba Boustanchi, who traveled for over 14 hours to be the voice of the Iranian people. - The Iranian regime has systematically violated human rights, imprisoned and executed political opponents and suppressed women for several decades. Due to the ongoing and serious situation in Iran, we have gathered here to be the voice of the Iranian people, she says on board the bus on the way to Munich. - We must show the outside world that we agree with each other both outside and inside Iran. We want to draw the world's attention to Iran, she continues. Fariba is one of many Iranians who hope for regime change in Iran. She calls for international support and expresses support for former Crown Prince Reza Pahlavi. - Iranians have expressed very clearly for several years that the Iranian regime is not our representative and that they do not want the mullahs as leaders in Iran. - We demand international recognition of the crown prince as a legitimate representative of Iran. He is the only reliable leader in the opposition to the Islamic regime from
8a9b798f47ae7d5298ea86ca6aa05c786a75f00e: The sadness of the restaurants - that Valentine's Day is on a Saturday
964ca04ff4f7dd3b30a19b9f9a8b1273c7c48c5b:
This year, Saturday does not give the same extra boost as when Valentine's Day falls on a weekday. Saturdays are already popular for restaurant visits, while weekdays usually get a bigger boost from the holiday. 
 
Most of the reservations for the restaurants on Valentine's Day are for two people, but since it is Saturday, larger groups can also show up, which sometimes affects the intimate atmosphere. 
  
- It can be very intimate and the sound level can be a little lower. But we in the staff usually make sure that everyone feels comfortable and can talk. We joke and sing. It will be nice for everyone here, says Felicia Bonaccorso. Many restaurants fully booked Bonaccorso has been fully booked for several months before Valentine's Day. According to BokaBord, which made a compilation of reservations from 440 restaurants in Stockholm, nearly 70 percent are fully booked during dinner time on Valentine's Day. The booking situation is roughly the same as last year, with an increase of just under two percent. 
  
- When I was inside myself looking for a free table for two on BokaBord, I saw that there are only 129 restaurants that have a free table tomorrow, compared to 400 restaurants in Stockholm on a normal Saturday, says Peder Dinkelspiel, founder of BokaBord.  Strained financial situation Despite the fact that the booking situation is good, many restaurants continue to have a tough time financially. Many are struggling to repay tax deferrals from the pandemic and guests are spending less than before. 
  
- The booking situation looks good and it is true. But the notes are smaller. Many restaurateurs testify to that, says Peder Dinkelspiel.
22892f7a103f3a9e1818c0a00d4c435a3f858aa2: The baby Emanuel is to be deported to Iran - then the organization warns
eca31a271892de78316ca12411fa4c04ba9439dc: According to Rädda Barnen, it is unlikely that the legislators intended that newborn children should be able to be deported when their parents have the right to stay in Sweden. In Emanuel's case, the decision is based on the fact that the rules for so-called track change were changed shortly before his birth - without transitional provisions for families who were already in the country. - I am convinced that no legislator imagined that this could be the consequence. But when many major changes are implemented in a short time, no one has time to review the consequences, says children's rights lawyer Karin Sjömilla. The Prime Minister: "Sounds unreasonable" Several leading politicians have reacted to the case. Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson has called the data "unreasonable". Even Ebba Busch has described the situation as unreasonable, and Jimmie Åkesson has said that he does not believe there is legal support for deporting an eight-month-old baby. Recently, several high-profile cases have involved children and teenagers who are at risk of deportation. Among other things, the discussion has been about possible exceptions for certain groups, such as so-called high school youth. But point efforts are not enough, says Karin Sjömilla. Save the Children instead calls for a broad review of the legislation at its core, to ensure that the best interests of the child actually have an impact. "The best interests of the child must be put aside" Among other things, the possibility to grant a residence permit due to "particularly painful circumstances" has been removed and replaced with the significantly more restrictive requirement "particularly painful reasons", something which has had major consequences according to Karin Sjömilla. - It is a very strict limitation. At the same time, politics sends the signal that as few as possible should be allowed to stay. This leads to the rules being interpreted narrowly, and then the best interests of the child often have to take a backseat to the principle of regulated immigration, she says. According to the Convention on the Rights of the Child, the best interests of the child must be a fundamental starting point in all decisions concerning children. But in practice, that principle does not have enough impact, says Karin Sjömil

d7da46b8db8e514f3f2d5931e66753d979c20be3: Ambulance personnel scooped up Leo, 77 - praised for the effort
47c3b9b807781768a8e6c4684c82babc31d82297: When Leo Selmerhagen returned home to Tomelilla in Skåne after a week at his special home, he was greeted by an unexpected sight – a two-metre high wall of snow blocked the entrance.   - I was totally blown away. I will never be able to do this, I thought. He didn't get in with the car and had to get in through a small crack.  - I barely got through the door. Took help via Facebook Leo is wary of physical exertion due to heart problems and therefore took help via the Facebook group Anslagstavlan Österlen. Shortly afterwards, an ambulance rolled into the lot. - I thought it was Särbo who had called as a precaution. But it wasn't like that. It turned out that the ambulance nurses Annette Lindelöf and David Sunesson had seen Leo's appeal and since they had time to spare – they rushed out to help. - They jumped out of the car and said "Hurry up, give us each a shovel" and then they started bouncing like two snow blowers, says Leo Selmerhagen.  "Shows empathy" Since the paramedics were nearby, there was no hesitation in going there.  - For us, it was obvious to help. It is not difficult to extend a helping hand and you yourself feel very good about it, says Annette Lindelöf to Ystads Allehanda.   Leo Selmerhagen lives at a height where it is usually very windy. He calls the place "Windy hill" and is used to a lot of snow, but this time it was unusually heavy. - I have been in the air force in Luleå, but this was seven trips worse. The incident was documented and posted on Facebook, where the effort has been met with many positive comments and tributes. - This shows the empathy that is needed in the world, says Leo Selmerhagen.
2865e17ab0cef2b0c8abba2d655b2b061fc721fe: Increased safety in the mountains ahead of the sports holiday
83836fa6f8cac76367545deb94cc39232188587b:
This ski season, there have been several serious incidents at the Swedish mountain destinations. 
In December, a 20-year-old man died in one of the ski slopes in Åre, and at the beginning of January, a 45-year-old man died in Björnrike in Vemdalen. What caused the fatal accidents is currently being investigated, but the events have shed light on the state of safety on the slopes at the ski resorts. 

In Lofsdalen there have been no serious incidents this winter, but there have been some incidents where skiers have injured themselves on the slopes.  - There have been a few knee injuries and wrist injuries. says Jonny Larsson, site manager in Lofsdalen.

 How do you work to make the slopes as safe as possible? 

- We put nets and mattresses on obstacles so the skiers don't injure themselves, and we inform them that we have low-speed zones through signs on the slopes, says Jonny Larsson, site manager in Lofsdalen. Many have been injured on the slopes When TV4 talks to holidaymakers on the ski slope, several of them say that they have at some point injured themselves on the ski slope or have friends or relatives who have been affected. - My daughter was riding and was inattentive and destroyed her knee, not that it broke completely, but got a stretch on both ligaments and cruciate ligaments, says Anders Börjesson. But there are things to keep in mind to reduce the risk of injury on the ski slopes. For example, using a helmet and other protection, having the right settings on your ski bindings, adjusting your speed and training your core and leg strength before you go on a skiing holiday. - I think a bit like this: No one goes to a cross-country competition without training first. The same should apply to downhill skiing. That you have trained your muscles a little before you go to the mountains and go slaloming or snowboarding for a whole week, says ski instructor Stella Elm.

73120b93a35ae0b3400a8970fc8a0931f493b3ea: The duo will break the world record in ping-pong – aiming for 24 hours
9a5d85a0a3681a613accc1b96f37a3eeb36d4e06: The last time "The spin duo" tried to break a new world record, they failed after just over 13 hours of playing. In the past, those who have stood the longest have stood for 15 hours and 49 minutes, but now the goal is to play for an entire day without dropping the ball. The current world record of 16 hours and 2 seconds was set by two people in the Netherlands.   Practical challenges Playing table tennis for 24 hours requires some preparation. Fredrik Nilsson says that this time they have a special plan for toilet visits. - We will run with the classic adult diaper this time. We can't pee ourselves in live broadcast, he says in Efter fem. - Even if you have Northern Europe's best bladder, you have to drive 24 hours, so better to be safe than sorry, adds Emil Ohlsson. But it is only number one that is relevant, the duo underlines. - Nothing else comes up, says Fredrik Nilsson. "It will be too boring" The player duo tells us that there will be officials on site in Västerås. During the record attempt, they will receive viewer questions and talk a lot, something that will be important to keep the concentration up.   - If we hadn't talked to the audience, we would never have managed to set a world record. It will be too boring, simply, to stand with Emil for 24 hours, says Fredrik Nilsson. - Even though we are damn good friends, we get tired of each other too, says Emil Ohlsson. "Will drive straight into the tile" The duo are determined to play for 24 hours and in doing so also beat the current record of 16 hours and two seconds.  - We have to take that away from them, says Fredrik.  - That is priority one, but then we will drive straight into the tile, concludes Emil.
5bb386f0e232933cef39ebd3a26d476887fd5143: New ice day in sight - here it could be minus 40 this weekend
523c376baed9a78908a329341fb1ced9029184c5:
This year's winter has been a cold story. For several weeks the temperature has been well below zero. The chilly weather is expected to last. And during Saturday, even lower temperatures are expected, down to minus 37-40 in Gielas, in the Västerbottenfjällen.

- The cold air is already about to swing in from the northeast, because the high pressure is strengthening and taking the cold air with it to the south, says Ulrika Elvgren, TV4 meteorologist. Colder January for a long time January has been colder than normal throughout the country. In Pajala the coldest since the measurements started in 1940. In Karesuando the coldest since 1893. In many places in the Tornedalen January has been among the three coldest that have been measured. 

- The coldest so far this year has been minus 40.8 degrees in Gielas on January 4. And here it can be down to 40 degrees this weekend. Last year's lowest temperature in the country was minus 36 degrees, says Ulrika Elvgren. High pressure over Sweden has been blocked The fact that the cold has kept Sweden in a firm grip for so long is because a high pressure over Scandinavia has been blocked. In summer the high pressure causes heat waves, in winter they cause the cold to linger.

- We have had high pressure since January, and right now there is nothing that breaks it down. It's because we don't have any jet streams here, they go by the Mediterranean Sea, where they cause storm Nils, among other things, says Ulrika Elvgren.

According to researchers, the fact that the jet streams have lost power is due to the climate changes affecting the Earth's polar regions.

- The jet streams that run in a north-south direction have lost their sting, which allows the cold air to get from the polar regions and south. We would need traction from jet streams to bring up some heat from the south, says Ulrika Elvgren. Chilly for the rest of the month But right now there are no such signs. The cold will last, shows SMHI's long-term forecast. 

- It will probably be cold for the rest of the month. And in March, you don't yet see that the jet streams change to any great degree. We have a real winter this year, says Ulrika Elvgren.
